å¦‚ä½•åœ¨Pythonä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ä»£ç†

æ€»ç»“

å‰è¨€

ä½ æ˜¯å¦é‡åˆ°è¿‡è¿™æ ·çš„æƒ…å†µï¼šå½“æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨çŸ­æ—¶é—´åå¤æŠ“å–ä¸€ä¸ªç½‘ç«™æ—¶ï¼Œç”±äºè¯·æ±‚è¿‡äºé¢‘ç¹ï¼Œæˆ–è€…è¯·æ±‚ç½‘ç»œçš„æ—¶å€™æ²¡æœ‰å…³é—­è¯·æ±‚ç«¯å£(resp.close())ï¼ŒæœåŠ¡å™¨å°±ä¼šå¯¹æˆ‘ä»¬çš„IPè¿›è¡Œå°é”è¾¾åˆ°åçˆ¬çš„ç›®çš„ã€‚è¿™ä¸ªæ—¶å€™æˆ‘ä»¬è¯¥æ€ä¹ˆåŠï¼Ÿç­”æ¡ˆå°±æ˜¯é€šè¿‡ç½‘ç»œä»£ç†çš„æ–¹å¼æ¥è§£å†³ã€‚

åœ¨è¿™é‡Œç‰¹åˆ«è¯´æ˜ï¼šç½‘ç»œä»£ç†æ·±å…¥äº†è§£çš„è¯ä¼šæ¶‰åŠåˆ°ä¸€äº›ç°è‰²äº§ä¸šï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸åˆ°ä¸‡ä¸å¾—å·²åƒä¸‡ä¸è¦è´¸ç„¶å»ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¹³æ—¥å°ä½“é‡çš„çˆ¬è™«æ˜¯ä¸è¶³ä»¥è®©æœåŠ¡å™¨å°é”IPçš„ï¼Œé™¤éæˆ‘ä»¬çš„IPå·²ç»å› ä¸ºå„ç§è«åå…¶å¦™åŸå› è¢«å°é”ï¼Œæˆ–è€…æˆ‘ä»¬çš„çˆ¬è™«ä½“é‡å¤ªå¤§ï¼Œéœ€è¦ä¸€ç§’é’Ÿå†…è¦è®¿é—®ä¸Šä¸‡æ¬¡ç­‰ï¼Œè¿™äº›æƒ…å†µæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é€‚åº¦ä½¿ç”¨ç½‘ç»œä»£ç†æ¥ä¿è¯å·¥ç¨‹è¿›è¡Œã€‚

ä»£ç†çš„åŸç†

ç”±å›¾å¯çŸ¥ï¼Œç›®æ ‡æœåŠ¡å™¨æ¥æ”¶åˆ°çš„æ˜¯ä»£ç†æœåŠ¡å™¨çš„è¯·æ±‚ï¼Œè¯·æ±‚ä¸­åŒ…å«çš„IPä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä»£ç†æœåŠ¡å™¨çš„IPï¼Œå®ƒä¸çŸ¥é“åœ¨ä»£ç†èƒŒåçš„ä½ çš„IPã€‚è¿™æ ·å°±èƒ½é¿å…æœ¬æœºIPæš´éœ²åœ¨ç›®æ ‡æœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸­ï¼Œä»è€Œé¿å…è¢«å°é”çš„é£é™©ã€‚

entry.title: 13. Practical: Scraping Outsourcing Info with XPath
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 13. Practical: Scraping Outsourcing Info with XPath
ğŸ“Š 579 views | ğŸ‘ 5 likes | ğŸ’¬ 5 comments | â­ 4 favorites

Table of Contents

Introduction

Approach

Code Implementation

Step 1: Get page source code

Step 2: Parse with XPath HTML parser

Step 3: Inspect source code and get XPath path

Step 4: Create CSV file for data writing

Step 5: Iterate through all divs to get needed information

Complete Code

Results

Summary

Introduction

Through previous chapters, weâ€™ve learned XPath basic syntax. This chapter uses a more complex website for practice - it has many nested tags, perfect for training.

Approach

  1. Get page source code
  2. Extract and parse data
  3. Save data to CSV file

Code Implementation

Step 1: Get page source code

Step 2: Parse with XPath HTML parser

Step 3: Inspect source code and get XPath path

Note: This step may have issues because the website changes dynamically. You canâ€™t use absolute paths directly - use unique attributes for precise positioning. You can also inspect source code, copy XPath path, then fine-tune.

Right-click the service provider section, click Inspect to jump to the corresponding code segment. Moving the mouse shows which section each tag wraps.

Through observation, we find the tags we need. After copying the absolute path and removing [1] from the last tag, we can get all similar service provider sections on this page - all search results. But we need to modify some preceding tag attribute values for positioning, otherwise we might get an empty list.

The final result looks like this:

Printing list length is for debugging. The source code shows 51 matching attribute values; excluding one outside our search range gives 50, matching our printed list length of 50 items.

Step 4: Create CSV file for data writing

Step 5: Iterate through all divs to get needed information

Similarly, search layer by layer, using the web developer toolsâ€™ highlighting to quickly find corresponding modules, or right-click elements to inspect. Use relative paths here - absolute paths would be too long. Note that some attribute values need modification for precise positioning, but not every one - this requires experience and trial-and-error.

Donâ€™t forget to close the file and network request at the end.

Complete Code

Results

We successfully scraped 50 results with high accuracy.

Summary

XPath parsing can be compared to file paths and bs4. I personally think itâ€™s like a combination of both, bringing together their advantages. This chapter used a complex practical case to scrape outsourcing website quotes, consolidating XPath parsing knowledge and skills. Next chapter, weâ€™ll advance our requests module learning.

entry.title: 14. Requests Advanced: Handling Login and Cookies
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 14. Requests Advanced: Handling Login and Cookies
ğŸ“Š 964 views | ğŸ‘ 3 likes | ğŸ’¬ 1 comment | â­ 6 favorites

Table of Contents

Introduction

Objective

Approach

Code Implementation

  1. Session Method

  2. Requests Method

Complete Code

Session Method

Requests Method

Summary

Introduction

Weâ€™ve already used headers in our previous scraping lessons. Headers are part of the HTTP protocolâ€™s request headers, generally storing data unrelated to request content, but sometimes containing security verification information like User-Agent, token, cookie, etc.

With requests, we can save header information to handle cookies, or store them separately - requests will automatically combine them into a complete HTTP request.

This chapter introduces a new concept: session. It remembers previously requested information and carries it to subsequent URL requests, similar to browser caching. Regular requests default to first-time access and donâ€™t remember cached visits.

Objective

Using a novel website as an example, weâ€™ll scrape the userâ€™s reading list using both requests and session methods.

Approach

  1. Login - get cookie
  2. Request bookshelf URL with cookie - get bookshelf content

Code Implementation

1. Session Method

First import and call the session interface, input username/password dictionary (register yourself and input):

Check network, get login URL, use session to request. Note: request method is POST:

Check network, get bookshelf URL, continue using session. Note: request method is GET:

2. Requests Method

After login, check browser Header info to get cookie, write directly into requests headers:

Get the bookshelf request URL and cookie:

Use your own cookie - everyoneâ€™s is different. Running this also shows successful results. Note: if the cookie contains double quotes, you canâ€™t wrap it with double quotes - use single quotes instead.

Complete Code

Session Method

Requests Method

Summary

Today we advanced our requests usage, learned about cookie security verification, practiced session usage, understood the session concept, and verified with a novel website example. Next chapter, weâ€™ll scrape video resources from a video website.

python url = "è§è¯„è®ºåŒº" resp = requests.get(url) # print(resp.text)

ç¬¬ä¸‰æ­¥ï¼Œé€šè¿‡æºä»£ç æ£€æŸ¥å¹¶è·å–XPathè·¯å¾„

æ³¨æ„ï¼Œè¿™ä¸€æ­¥å¾ˆæœ‰å¯èƒ½å‡ºç°é—®é¢˜ï¼Œå› ä¸ºè¿™ä¸ªç½‘ç«™æ˜¯ä¸€ç›´åœ¨åŠ¨æ€å˜åŒ–çš„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¸èƒ½ç›´æ¥ç”¨ç»å¯¹è·¯å¾„ï¼Œè€Œè¦ç”¨ä¸€äº›å”¯ä¸€çš„å±æ€§æ¥æ ‡å®šæ‰èƒ½ç²¾å‡†å®šä½ã€‚å½“ç„¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥å…ˆæ£€æŸ¥æºä»£ç å¹¶å¤åˆ¶XPathè·¯å¾„ï¼Œå†è¿›è¡Œå¾®è°ƒã€‚

å³å‡»æŸ¥è¯¢åˆ°çš„æœåŠ¡å•†æ¿å—ï¼Œå•å‡»æ£€æŸ¥ï¼Œå³å¯è·³è½¬åˆ°æºä»£ç å¯¹åº”çš„ä»£ç æ®µä¸­ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”ç§»åŠ¨é¼ æ ‡å¯ä»¥è§‚å¯Ÿåˆ°æ¯ä¸ªæ ‡ç­¾åŒ…è£¹çš„æ¿å—ã€‚

é€šè¿‡è§‚å¯Ÿå‘ç°è¿™é‡Œæ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„æ ‡ç­¾ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¤åˆ¶ç»å¯¹è·¯å¾„åå†æŠŠæœ€åä¸€ä¸ªæ ‡ç­¾çš„[1]åˆ æ‰ï¼Œå°±å¯ä»¥è·å–æœ¬é¡µé¢ä¸Šæ‰€æœ‰ç±»ä¼¼çš„æœåŠ¡å•†æ¿å—äº†ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯æ‰€æœ‰çš„æŸ¥è¯¢ç»“æœã€‚ä½†æ˜¯æ ¹æ®å®é™…æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦ä¿®æ”¹ä¸€äº›å‰ç½®æ ‡ç­¾çš„å±æ€§å€¼æ¥å®šä½ï¼Œå¦åˆ™å¾ˆæœ‰å¯èƒ½æŠ“åˆ°ç©ºåˆ—è¡¨ã€‚

æœ€åæ‹¿åˆ°çš„æ•ˆæœæ˜¯è¿™æ ·çš„ï¼š

python # æ‹¿åˆ°æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæœåŠ¡å•†çš„div divs = html.xpath("/html/body/div[@id='__nuxt']/div[@id='__layout']/div[@class='app-page-layout']/div[3]/div[@class='s50-search-list-page']/div[4]/div[4]/div[1]/div[@class='service-card-wrap']") # print(len(divs))

æ‰“å°åˆ—è¡¨é•¿åº¦æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†debugï¼Œåœ¨æºä»£ç ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾æœ€åçš„å±æ€§å€¼ä¸º51ä¸ªï¼Œé™¤å»æˆ‘ä»¬æŸ¥æ‰¾èŒƒå›´å¤–çš„ä¸€ä¸ªæ­£å¥½ä¸º50ä¸ªï¼Œè€Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ‰“å°å‡ºæ¥çš„åˆ—è¡¨é•¿åº¦ä¹Ÿæ˜¯50ï¼Œè¯´æ˜æ‰¾åˆ°äº†50ä¸ªå­é¡¹ï¼Œæ˜¯å¯¹åº”çš„ã€‚

ç¬¬å››æ­¥ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºcsvæ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œå‡†å¤‡å†™å…¥æ•°æ®

python with open("çŒªå…«æˆ’Java.csv", mode="a+", newline='', encoding="utf-8") as f: csvwriter = csv.writer(f)

ç¬¬äº”æ­¥ï¼Œéå†æ‰€æœ‰çš„divï¼Œè·å–æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„ä¿¡æ¯

python for div in divs: # æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæœåŠ¡å•†ä¿¡æ¯ price = div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div/span/text()")[0].strip("ï¿¥") title = "Java".join(div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div[2]/a/text()")) score = div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div[4]/div[@class='fraction']/span[1]/text()")[0] sales = div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div[4]/div[@class='sales']/div/span[2]/text()")[0] evaluate = div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div[4]/div[@class='evaluate']/div/span[2]/text()")[0] company_name = div.xpath("./div/a/div[2]/div[1]/div/text()")[0] csvwriter.writerow([title, price, score, sales, evaluate, company_name]) f.close() print("Overï¼")

åŒç†ï¼Œéœ€è¦ä¸€å±‚ä¸€å±‚å»æ‰¾ï¼Œé…åˆç½‘é¡µå¼€å‘å·¥å…·çš„é«˜äº®æç¤ºå¯¹åº”æ¨¡å—å¿«é€Ÿæ‰¾åˆ°ï¼Œæˆ–è€…åœ¨ç½‘é¡µä¸­å°†é¼ æ ‡ç§»åŠ¨åˆ°å¯¹åº”å…ƒç´ ä¸Šå³å‡»æ£€æŸ¥æ‰¾åˆ°ç›®æ ‡ã€‚æ­¤æ—¶æˆ‘ä»¬è¦ç”¨ç›¸å¯¹è·¯å¾„æ¥æ‰¾ï¼Œå¦åˆ™å¤ªé•¿äº†ã€‚æ³¨æ„è¿™é‡Œä¹Ÿè¦é€‚å½“çš„ä¿®æ”¹ä¸€äº›å±æ€§å€¼æ¥ç²¾å‡†å®šä½ï¼Œä½†ä¸æ˜¯æ¯ä¸€æ¡éƒ½è¦ä¿®æ”¹å±æ€§å€¼ï¼Œè¿™å°±éœ€è¦ç»éªŒå’Œè¯•é”™äº†ã€‚

å½“ç„¶ï¼Œæœ€ååˆ«å¿˜è®°å…³é—­æ–‡ä»¶å’Œå…³é—­ç½‘ç»œè¯·æ±‚ã€‚

å®Œæ•´ä»£ç 

python # Created at UESTC # Author: Vector Kun # Time: 2023/1/2 23:55 # æ‹¿åˆ°é¡µé¢æºä»£ç  # æå–å’Œè§£ææ•°æ® import requests from lxml import etree import csv url = "è§è¯„è®ºåŒº" resp = requests.get(url) # print(resp.text) # è§£æ html = etree.HTML(resp.text) # æ‹¿åˆ°æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæœåŠ¡å•†çš„div divs = html.xpath("/html/body/div[@id='__nuxt']/div[@id='__layout']/div[@class='app-page-layout']/div[3]/div[@class='s50-search-list-page']/div[4]/div[4]/div[1]/div[@class='service-card-wrap']") # print(len(divs)) with open("çŒªå…«æˆ’Java.csv", mode="a+", newline='', encoding="utf-8") as f: csvwriter = csv.writer(f) for div in divs: # æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæœåŠ¡å•†ä¿¡æ¯ price = div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div/span/text()")[0].strip("ï¿¥") title = "Java".join(div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div[2]/a/text()")) score = div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div[4]/div[@class='fraction']/span[1]/text()")[0] sales = div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div[4]/div[@class='sales']/div/span[2]/text()")[0] evaluate = div.xpath("./div/div[@class='bot-content']/div[4]/div[@class='evaluate']/div/span[2]/text()")[0] company_name = div.xpath("./div/a/div[2]/div[1]/div/text()")[0] csvwriter.writerow([title, price, score, sales, evaluate, company_name]) f.close() print("Overï¼") resp.close()

è¿è¡Œç»“æœ

å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°æˆ‘ä»¬æˆåŠŸæŠ“å–äº†50æ¡ç»“æœï¼Œç»“æœååˆ†å‡†ç¡®ã€‚

æ€»ç»“

XPathè§£ææ–¹æ³•å¯ä»¥å’Œæ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„ä¸bs4ä½œç±»æ¯”ï¼Œæˆ‘ä¸ªäººè§‰å¾—å®ƒç‰¹åˆ«åƒä¸¤è€…çš„ç»“åˆä½“ï¼ŒæŠŠä»–ä»¬çš„ä¼˜ç‚¹é›†åˆåˆ°ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œå–é•¿è¡¥çŸ­è¿›è¡Œäº’è¡¥ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬æœ¬èŠ‚é€šè¿‡ä¸€ä¸ªæ¯”è¾ƒå¤æ‚çš„å®æˆ˜æ¡ˆä¾‹å®ç°å¤–åŒ…ç½‘ç«™æŠ¥ä»·ç­‰ä¿¡æ¯çš„è·å–ï¼Œå·©å›ºäº†XPathè§£æçš„çŸ¥è¯†å’Œè¿ç”¨èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚ä¸‹ä¸€èŠ‚å¼€å§‹æˆ‘ä»¬å°†å¯¹requestsæ¨¡å—è¿›è¡Œè¿›é˜¶å­¦ä¹ ã€‚

æœ¬ç« æˆ‘ä»¬å°†å¼•å…¥ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„æ¦‚å¿µï¼šä¼šè¯ï¼ˆsessionï¼‰ã€‚å®ƒä¼šè®°ä½ä»¥å‰è¯·æ±‚åˆ°çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå¹¶æ²¿ç”¨åˆ°åé¢çš„urlè¯·æ±‚ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼æµè§ˆå™¨çš„ç¼“å­˜æœºåˆ¶ã€‚è€Œrequestæ¯æ¬¡éƒ½é»˜è®¤æ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡è®¿é—®ï¼Œä¸ä¼šè®°ä½è®¿é—®çš„ç¼“å­˜ã€‚

ç›®çš„

æ€è·¯

ä»£ç å®ç°

é¦–å…ˆå¯¼åŒ…ï¼Œè°ƒç”¨sessionæ¥å£ï¼Œè¾“å…¥ç”¨æˆ·åå¯†ç å­—å…¸ä¿¡æ¯ï¼ˆè¿™é‡Œè‡ªå·±å»æ³¨å†Œä¸€ä¸‹è¾“å…¥å°±å¥½ï¼‰

python import requests # ä¼šè¯ session = requests.session() data = { "loginName": "TODO", "password": "TODO" }

æ£€æŸ¥ç½‘ç»œï¼Œè·å–ç™»å½•urlï¼Œä½¿ç”¨sessionè¯·æ±‚ï¼Œæ³¨æ„è¯·æ±‚æ–¹å¼ä¸ºpost

python # 1. ç™»å½• url = "https://passport.17k.com/ck/user/login" session.post(url, data=data) # print(resp.text) # print(resp.cookies) # çœ‹cookie

æ£€æŸ¥ç½‘ç»œï¼Œè·å–ä¹¦æ¶urlï¼Œç»§ç»­ä½¿ç”¨sessionè¯·æ±‚ï¼Œæ³¨æ„è¯·æ±‚æ–¹å¼ä¸ºget

python # 2. æ‹¿ä¹¦æ¶ä¸Šçš„æ•°æ® # åˆšæ‰çš„é‚£ä¸ªsessionä¸­æ˜¯æœ‰cookieçš„ resp = session.get('https://user.17k.com/ck/author/shelf?page=1&appKey=2406394919') print(resp.json())

2. requestsæ³•

ç™»é™†åæ£€æŸ¥æµè§ˆå™¨Headerä¿¡æ¯æ‹¿åˆ°cookieï¼Œåœ¨requestsè¯·æ±‚ä¸­ç›´æ¥å†™å…¥headersä¸­ï¼š

python cookie = 'TODO' resp = requests.get("https://user.17k.com/ck/author/shelf?page=1&appKey=2406394919", headers={"Cookie": cookie}) print(resp.text)

cookieç”¨è‡ªå·±çš„ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªäººçš„ä¸åŒã€‚è¿è¡Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°æˆåŠŸå¾—åˆ°ç»“æœã€‚è¿™é‡Œè¦æ³¨æ„å¦‚æœcookieé‡Œé¢æ˜¯åŒå¼•å·å°±ä¸èƒ½ç”¨åŒå¼•å·åŒ…è£¹ï¼Œè¦æ¢æˆå•å¼•å·ã€‚

python # ç™»å½• -> å¾—åˆ°cookie # å¸¦ç€cookie å»è¯·æ±‚åˆ°ä¹¦æ¶url -> ä¹¦æ¶ä¸Šçš„å†…å®¹ # å¿…é¡»å¾—æŠŠä¸Šé¢çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªæ“ä½œè¿èµ·æ¥ # æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨sessionè¿›è¡Œè¯·æ±‚ -> sessionä½ å¯ä»¥è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯ä¸€è¿ä¸²çš„è¯·æ±‚. åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­çš„cookieä¸ä¼šä¸¢å¤± import requests # ä¼šè¯ session = requests.session() data = { "loginName": "TODO", "password": "TODO" } # 1. ç™»å½• url = "https://passport.17k.com/ck/user/login" session.post(url, data=data) # print(resp.text) # print(resp.cookies) # çœ‹cookie # 2. æ‹¿ä¹¦æ¶ä¸Šçš„æ•°æ® # åˆšæ‰çš„é‚£ä¸ªsessionä¸­æ˜¯æœ‰cookieçš„ resp = session.get('https://user.17k.com/ck/author/shelf?page=1&appKey=2406394919') print(resp.json())

entry.title: 12. XPath Parsing Introduction
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 12. XPath Parsing Introduction
ğŸ“Š 611 views | ğŸ‘ 2 likes | ğŸ’¬ 1 comment | â­ 6 favorites

Table of Contents

Introduction

Module Installation

Basic XPath Concepts

XPath Basic Syntax

Complete Test Code

XPath Advanced Usage

Task 1: Process a resource file with xpath

Task 2: Find tag location, like html tag

Task 3: Find text content in each list item (li) of unordered list (ul)

Task 4: Find text content in first list item (li) of unordered list (ul)

Task 5: Find link (a) content in each list item (li) of unordered list (ul)

Task 6: Get text wrapped by href=â€™dapaoâ€™ (attribute filtering)

Task 7: Get list items, then recursively extract text and href attribute values

Task 8: Exercise: Print text info of first div

XPath Advanced Usage Complete Code

Introduction

XPath is a language for finding information in XML documents. XPath can traverse elements and attributes in XML documents. HTML happens to be a subset of XML, so XPath can be used to find content in HTML.

Module Installation

As usual, just pip install lxml

Basic XPath Concepts

Hereâ€™s an XML document:

First, understand these concepts:

  1. book, id, name, priceâ€¦ are all called nodes
  2. id, name, price, author are called child nodes of book
  3. book is called the parent node of id, name, price, author
  4. id, name, price, author are called sibling nodes

With this foundation, we can start learning XPath basic syntax.

XPath Basic Syntax

Using another XML example:

To use XPath parsing in Python, first learn how to import:

Import the etree module from the lxml library we just installed for XPath parsing.

Write the XML example to a file and process it with etree.XML():

Besides processing XML, etree also has etree.HTML() for HTML files and etree.parse() for resource files, which weâ€™ll use later.

XPath parsing is based on file-path-like syntax. Tags are nested, so this algorithm follows file path conventions.

To request the name tag, its XPath path is: /book/name. In code:

â€˜/â€˜ represents hierarchy. Linux/Mac users know the first â€˜/â€˜ is the root node. Windows file systems start with drive letters (C:/, etc.), but they also have a root node - itâ€™s just omitted for readability.

To request all nick tags wrapped by author tag, use XPath: /book/author/nick to get all nick tags on this path.

Printing result shows an iterator-like result with tag locations. But we want the text content or attribute values. Using /text gets the text tag location. So we use text() to get the text content wrapped by the found tag.

Similarly, get all names under /book/author/nick:

But what if we want all text from all nick tags inside author, including Hot1, Hot2, Hot3?

The double slash â€˜//â€˜ after author means get all descendant nick tags - there can be 0, 1, 2, 3, â€¦, n levels between them. All nick tags under author are captured.

For only one level of results:

The asterisk * between author and nick represents any tag name (wildcard), but only replaces one level, so it doesnâ€™t get Hot3 from /book/author/span/div/nick.

Practice: get all text wrapped by nick in this XML:

Simple - just add double slash after book.

Complete Test Code

When testing, comment out unnecessary code to easily view results, or use debug mode.

Quick tip: In PyCharm, use Ctrl+/ to comment selected lines.

XPath Advanced Usage

Using a simple HTML file to show more XPath capabilities:

Save as 7_xpath_eg.html in the same folder as your py file.

Task 1: Process a resource file with xpath

Here we use the parse function to process local resource files.

Task 2: Find tag location, like html tag

Found the tag location and its address.

Task 3: Find text content in each list item (li) of unordered list (ul)

Task 4: Find text content in first list item (li) of unordered list (ul)

Note: XPath doesnâ€™t start from 0 - index 1 is the first item.

Task 5: Find link (a) content in each list item (li) of unordered list (ul)

Use â€œ@attributeâ€ to get attribute values.

Task 6: Get text wrapped by href=â€™cannonâ€™ (attribute filtering)

Filter attributes by adding [@attribute=value] after the tag - similar to bs4â€™s approach.

Task 7: Get list items, then recursively extract text and href attribute values

./ means relative search from current path - â€˜.â€™ represents /html/body/ol/li.

Task 8: Exercise: Print text info of first div

XPath Advanced Usage Complete Code

Please comment/uncomment code sections for testing.

Summary

This chapter introduced XPath basics - processing XML and HTML files, and various XPath usage scenarios. Next chapter will be hands-on practice.

Weâ€™ve now learned three parsing methods. You can freely combine them to efficiently get the information you need.

entry.title: 11. Practical: Scraping Web Images with bs4 and Saving Locally
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 11. Practical: Scraping Web Images with bs4 and Saving Locally
ğŸ“Š 1654 views | ğŸ‘ 8 likes | ğŸ’¬ 6 comments | â­ 17 favorites

Introduction

Through previous chapters, weâ€™ve learned how convenient the bs4 module is for web scraping, and practiced with an example of scraping vegetable prices. In this chapter, weâ€™ll use an image website as an example to scrape wallpaper content and save it to a local folder.

Approach

  1. Get all sub-page link addresses
  2. Get image resource addresses from sub-pages
  3. Download images

Code Implementation

Step one, as usual, get the page source code first:

Step two, pass the source code to BeautifulSoup and find sub-links:

Step three, iterate through sub-links, get sub-page source code and image download paths:

Step four, download images:

The image download logic is simple: get the image in byte format and write it to a local folder in binary mode (wb stands for write byte).

Complete Code

Results

I scraped a portion and stopped - letâ€™s take it easy and just practice.

Tips: Since PyCharm traverses the project folder and updates file indexes whenever thereâ€™s an update, scraping too many images might slow down your IDE. You can right-click the created img folder, select â€œMark Directory asâ€¦â€, then choose â€œExcludedâ€. This tells PyCharm that this folder isnâ€™t part of the project scope, so it wonâ€™t spend effort indexing it every time.

Summary

Today we practiced a bs4 example, using the bs4 module to batch download wallpapers from a website to a local folder, improving our scraping skills. Next chapter, weâ€™ll start learning xpath.

å‰è¨€

æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡å‰é¢å‡ èŠ‚çš„å­¦ä¹ å·²ç»äº†è§£åˆ°bs4æ¨¡å—å¯¹äºæˆ‘ä»¬æŠ“å–ç½‘é¡µçš„æ–¹ä¾¿ä¹‹å¤„ï¼Œä¹Ÿé€šè¿‡ä¸€ä¸ªå®ä¾‹å®è·µäº†æŠ“å–æŸç½‘ç«™èœä»·ã€‚æœ¬èŠ‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä»¥æŸå›¾ç‰‡ç½‘ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼ˆé“¾æ¥æ”¾è¯„è®ºåŒº ï¼‰ï¼Œå®ç°æŠ“å–å”¯ç¾å£çº¸æ ç›®çš„å†…å®¹å¹¶ä¿å­˜åˆ°æœ¬åœ°æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ã€‚

ç›®æ ‡

æ€è·¯

1. è·å–æ‰€æœ‰å­é¡µé¢é“¾æ¥åœ°å€

2. è·å–å­é¡µé¢ä¸­å›¾ç‰‡èµ„æºåœ°å€

3. ä¸‹è½½å›¾ç‰‡

ä»£ç å®ç°

ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥ï¼Œè€è§„çŸ©ï¼Œå…ˆè·å–é¡µé¢æºä»£ç 

python import requests from bs4 import BeautifulSoup import time url = "åœ¨è¯„è®ºåŒº" resp = requests.get(url) resp.encoding = 'utf-8' # å¤„ç†ä¹±ç 

ç¬¬äºŒæ­¥ï¼ŒæŠŠæºä»£ç æ‰”ç»™BeautifulSoupå¤„ç†ï¼Œæ‰¾åˆ°å­é“¾æ¥

python # æŠŠæºä»£ç äº¤ç»™bs main_page = BeautifulSoup(resp.text, "html.parser") item_list = main_page.find_all("div", class_="item masonry_brick") alist = [] for item in item_list: find = item.find("a") alist.append(find) # print(alist)

ç¬¬ä¸‰æ­¥ï¼Œéå†è®¿é—®å­é“¾æ¥ï¼Œè·å–å­é¡µé¢æºä»£ç å¹¶æ‹¿åˆ°å›¾ç‰‡ä¸‹è½½è·¯å¾„

python for a in alist: href = 'https://www.umei.cc/' + a.get('href').strip("/") # ç›´æ¥é€šè¿‡getå°±å¯ä»¥æ‹¿åˆ°å±æ€§çš„å€¼ # æ‹¿åˆ°å­é¡µé¢çš„æºä»£ç  child_page_resp = requests.get(href) child_page_resp.encoding = 'utf-8' child_page_text = child_page_resp.text # ä»å­é¡µé¢ä¸­æ‹¿åˆ°å›¾ç‰‡çš„ä¸‹è½½è·¯å¾„ child_page = BeautifulSoup(child_page_text, "html.parser") div = child_page.find("div", class_="big-pic") img = div.find("img") src = img.get("src")

ç¬¬å››æ­¥ï¼Œä¸‹è½½å›¾ç‰‡

python # ä¸‹è½½å›¾ç‰‡ img_resp = requests.get(src) # img_resp.content # è¿™é‡Œæ‹¿åˆ°çš„æ˜¯å­—èŠ‚ img_name = src.split("/")[-1] # æ‹¿åˆ°urlä¸­çš„æœ€åä¸€ä¸ª/ä»¥åçš„å†…å®¹ with open("img8/" + img_name, mode="wb") as f: f.write(img_resp.content) # å›¾ç‰‡å†…å®¹å†™å…¥æ–‡ä»¶ print("over!!!", img_name) time.sleep(1) print("all over!!!")

ä¸‹è½½å›¾ç‰‡çš„æ€è·¯å¾ˆç®€å•ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦æ‹¿åˆ°å›¾ç‰‡çš„å­—èŠ‚å½¢å¼ï¼Œå¹¶ç”¨äºŒè¿›åˆ¶æ–¹å¼å†™å…¥æœ¬åœ°æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ï¼ˆwbä¸ºäºŒè¿›åˆ¶å†™ï¼Œå¾ˆæ˜æ˜¾æ˜¯write byteçš„ç¼©å†™å˜›ï¼‰

å®Œæ•´ä»£ç 

python # 1.æ‹¿åˆ°ä¸»é¡µé¢çš„æºä»£ç . ç„¶åæå–åˆ°å­é¡µé¢çš„é“¾æ¥åœ°å€, href # 2.é€šè¿‡hrefæ‹¿åˆ°å­é¡µé¢çš„å†…å®¹. ä»å­é¡µé¢ä¸­æ‰¾åˆ°å›¾ç‰‡çš„ä¸‹è½½åœ°å€ img -> src # 3.ä¸‹è½½å›¾ç‰‡ import requests from bs4 import BeautifulSoup import time url = "è§è¯„è®ºåŒº" resp = requests.get(url) resp.encoding = 'utf-8' # å¤„ç†ä¹±ç  # print(resp.text) # æŠŠæºä»£ç äº¤ç»™bs main_page = BeautifulSoup(resp.text, "html.parser") item_list = main_page.find_all("div", class_="item masonry_brick") alist = [] for item in item_list: find = item.find("a") alist.append(find) # print(alist) for a in alist: href = 'https://www.umei.cc/' + a.get('href').strip("/") # ç›´æ¥é€šè¿‡getå°±å¯ä»¥æ‹¿åˆ°å±æ€§çš„å€¼ # æ‹¿åˆ°å­é¡µé¢çš„æºä»£ç  child_page_resp = requests.get(href) child_page_resp.encoding = 'utf-8' child_page_text = child_page_resp.text # ä»å­é¡µé¢ä¸­æ‹¿åˆ°å›¾ç‰‡çš„ä¸‹è½½è·¯å¾„ child_page = BeautifulSoup(child_page_text, "html.parser") div = child_page.find("div", class_="big-pic") img = div.find("img") src = img.get("src") # ä¸‹è½½å›¾ç‰‡ img_resp = requests.get(src) # img_resp.content # è¿™é‡Œæ‹¿åˆ°çš„æ˜¯å­—èŠ‚ img_name = src.split("/")[-1] # æ‹¿åˆ°urlä¸­çš„æœ€åä¸€ä¸ª/ä»¥åçš„å†…å®¹ with open("img8/" + img_name, mode="wb") as f: f.write(img_resp.content) # å›¾ç‰‡å†™å…¥æ–‡ä»¶ print("over!!!", img_name) time.sleep(1) print("all over!!!")

è¿è¡Œæ•ˆæœ

æˆ‘çˆ¬å–äº†ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†å°±åœäº†ï¼Œå’±è¿˜æ˜¯æ‚ ç€ç‚¹ï¼Œç»ƒç»ƒæ‰‹å°±å¥½äº†ã€‚

Tipsï¼šç”±äºPyCharmæ¯æ¬¡åœ¨é¡¹ç›®æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹æœ‰æ›´æ–°æ—¶ï¼Œéƒ½ä¼šéå†ä¸€æ¬¡æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ï¼Œæ›´æ–°æ–‡ä»¶ç´¢å¼•ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬çˆ¬å–å›¾ç‰‡å¤ªå¤šçš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå¾ˆæœ‰å¯èƒ½ä¼šåœ¨è¿™ä¸€æ­¥è®©æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ç¼–è¯‘è½¯ä»¶è¶Šæ¥è¶Šå¡ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¯ä»¥å³å‡»åˆ›å»ºçš„imgæ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ï¼Œé€‰æ‹©Mark Directory asâ€¦ï¼Œå†é€‰æ‹©Excludedï¼Œè¿™æ ·å°±æ˜¯å‘Šè¯‰PyCharmï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è¿™ä¸ªæ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ä¸å±äºé¡¹ç›®è°ƒç”¨çš„èŒƒç•´ï¼Œå®ƒä¹Ÿå°±ä¸ä¼šæ¯æ¬¡éƒ½èŠ±åŠ›æ°”å¯¹å®ƒç´¢å¼•äº†ã€‚

æ€»ç»“

ä»Šå¤©æˆ‘ä»¬æ“ä½œäº†bs4çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå®æˆ˜ä¾‹å­ï¼Œè¿ç”¨bs4æ¨¡å—å¯¹æŸç½‘ç«™çš„å”¯ç¾å£çº¸è¿›è¡Œæ‰¹é‡ä¸‹è½½åˆ°æœ¬åœ°æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹çš„æ“ä½œï¼Œæå‡äº†çˆ¬è™«æŠ€æœ¯ã€‚ä¸‹ä¸€èŠ‚æˆ‘ä»¬å°†å¼€å§‹xpathçš„æ•™å­¦ã€‚

entry.content:
æœ¬æ–‡è¿ç§»è‡ªCSDNåšå®¢

XPathæ¶‰åŠçš„åŸºæœ¬æ¦‚å¿µ

éœ€æ±‚1ï¼šè®©xpathå¤„ç†è¿™ä¸ªèµ„æºæ–‡ä»¶

éœ€æ±‚2ï¼šæ‰¾åˆ°æ ‡ç­¾ä½ç½®ï¼Œå¦‚htmlæ ‡ç­¾

éœ€æ±‚3ï¼šæ‰¾åˆ°æ— åºåˆ—è¡¨(ul)ä¸­æ¯ä¸€é¡¹(li)åŒ…è£¹çš„æ–‡æœ¬å†…å®¹

éœ€æ±‚4ï¼šæ‰¾åˆ°æ— åºåˆ—è¡¨(ul)ä¸­ç¬¬ä¸€é¡¹(li)åŒ…è£¹çš„æ–‡æœ¬å†…å®¹

éœ€æ±‚5ï¼šæ‰¾åˆ°æ— åºåˆ—è¡¨(ul)ä¸­æ¯ä¸€é¡¹(li)åŒ…è£¹çš„é“¾æ¥(a)å†…å®¹

éœ€æ±‚6ï¼šè·å–hrefä¸ºâ€˜dapaoâ€™åŒ…è£¹çš„æ–‡å­—ï¼ˆå±æ€§ç­›é€‰ï¼‰

éœ€æ±‚7ï¼šå…ˆè·å–åˆ—è¡¨é¡¹ï¼Œå†é€’å½’æ¯ä¸ªåˆ—è¡¨é¡¹å–å‡ºåŒ…è£¹æ–‡æœ¬å’Œaæ ‡ç­¾çš„hrefå±æ€§å€¼

éœ€æ±‚8ï¼šç»ƒä¹ ï¼šæ‰“å°ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªdivçš„æ–‡æœ¬ä¿¡æ¯

XPathè¿›é˜¶ç”¨æ³•å®Œæ•´ä»£ç 

å‰è¨€

XPathæ˜¯ä¸€é—¨åœ¨ XML æ–‡æ¡£ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾ä¿¡æ¯çš„è¯­è¨€ã€‚XPathå¯ç”¨æ¥åœ¨ XML æ–‡æ¡£ä¸­å¯¹å…ƒç´ å’Œå±æ€§è¿›è¡Œéå†ã€‚è€Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç†ŸçŸ¥çš„HTMLæ°å·§å±äºXMLçš„â¼€ä¸ªå­é›†ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å®Œå…¨å¯ä»¥ç”¨XPathå»æŸ¥æ‰¾htmlä¸­çš„å†…å®¹ã€‚

æ¨¡å—å®‰è£…

è€æ ·å­ï¼Œç›´æ¥pip install lxml

XPathæ¶‰åŠçš„åŸºæœ¬æ¦‚å¿µ

ä¸‹é¢æ˜¯ä¸€æ®µxmlæ–‡æ¡£ï¼š

XML <book> <id>1</id> <name>é‡èŠ±éåœ°é¦™</name> <price>1.23</price> <author> <nick>å‘¨å¤§å¼º</nick> <nick>å‘¨èŠ·è‹¥</nick> </author> </book>

é¦–å…ˆï¼Œå…ˆäº†è§£å‡ ä¸ªæ¦‚å¿µï¼š

1. book, id, name, priceâ€¦.éƒ½è¢«ç§°ä¸ºèŠ‚ç‚¹.

2. Id, name, price, authorè¢«ç§°ä¸ºbookçš„å­èŠ‚ç‚¹

3. bookè¢«ç§°ä¸ºid, name, price, authorçš„çˆ¶èŠ‚ç‚¹

4. id, name, price,authorè¢«ç§°ä¸ºåŒèƒèŠ‚ç‚¹

OK~ æœ‰äº†è¿™äº›åŸºç¡€çŸ¥è¯†å, æˆ‘ä»¬å°±å¯ä»¥å¼€å§‹äº†è§£xpathçš„åŸºæœ¬è¯­æ³•äº†

XPathåŸºæœ¬è¯­æ³•

è¿˜æ˜¯ä»¥ä¸€æ®µxmlä¸ºä¾‹ï¼š

XML <book> <id>1</id> <name>é‡èŠ±éåœ°é¦™</name> <price>1.23</price> <nick>è‡­è±†è…</nick> <author> <nick id="10086">å‘¨å¤§å¼º</nick> <nick id="10010">å‘¨èŠ·è‹¥</nick> <nick class="jay">å‘¨æ°ä¼¦</nick> <nick class="jolin">è”¡ä¾æ—</nick> <div> <nick>çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­1</nick> </div> <span> <nick>çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­2</nick> <div> <nick>çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­3</nick> </div> </span> </author> <partner> <nick id="ppc">èƒ–èƒ–é™ˆ</nick> <nick id="ppbc">èƒ–èƒ–ä¸é™ˆ</nick> </partner> </book>

è¦æƒ³åœ¨Pythonä¸­ä½¿ç”¨XPathè§£ææ–¹å¼ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è¦å…ˆå­¦ä¼šæ€ä¹ˆå¯¼åŒ…ã€‚

python from lxml import etree

ä»æˆ‘ä»¬åˆšåˆšä¸‹è½½å¥½çš„lxmlåº“ä¸­å¯¼å…¥etreeæ¨¡å—ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å°±èƒ½è¿›è¡ŒXPathè§£æäº†ã€‚

æˆ‘ä»¬æŠŠä¸Šé¢çš„xmlèŒƒä¾‹å†™å…¥æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œç”¨etree.XML()æ¥å¤„ç†è¿™æ®µä¿¡æ¯ï¼š

python xml = """ <book> <id>1</id> <name>é‡èŠ±éåœ°é¦™</name> <price>1.23</price> <nick>è‡­è±†è…</nick> <author> <nick id="10086">å‘¨å¤§å¼º</nick> <nick id="10010">å‘¨èŠ·è‹¥</nick> <nick class="jay">å‘¨æ°ä¼¦</nick> <nick class="jolin">è”¡ä¾æ—</nick> <div> <nick>çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­1</nick> </div> <span> <nick>çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­2</nick> <div> <nick>çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­3</nick> </div> </span> </author> <partner> <nick id="ppc">èƒ–èƒ–é™ˆ</nick> <nick id="ppbc">èƒ–èƒ–ä¸é™ˆ</nick> </partner> </book> """ tree = etree.XML(xml)

ä¸ä»…å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œetreeä¸‹é™¤äº†å¤„ç†xmlçš„apiè¿˜å¯ä»¥ç”¨etree.HTML()æ¥å¤„ç†htmlç±»å‹æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œè¿˜å¯ä»¥ç”¨etree.parse()æ¥å¤„ç†èµ„æºæ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬åç»­ä¼šç”¨åˆ°ã€‚

æˆ‘ä»¬XPathæ˜¯åŸºäºç±»ä¼¼æ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„æ¥è§£æçš„ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°æ ‡ç­¾éƒ½æ˜¯äº’ç›¸åµŒå¥—çš„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥è¿™ç§ç®—æ³•å­¦ä¹ äº†æ–‡ä»¶è·¯å¾„ã€‚

æ¯”å¦‚æˆ‘ä»¬æƒ³è¯·æ±‚nameæ ‡ç­¾ï¼Œå®ƒçš„XPathè·¯å¾„å°±æ˜¯ï¼š/book/nameã€‚å†™ä¸ºä»£ç ï¼š

python result = tree.xpath("/book/name")

â€˜/â€™è¡¨ç¤ºå±‚çº§å…³ç³»ã€‚ç†Ÿæ‚‰Linuxçš„æˆ–è€…ç”¨Macçš„åº”è¯¥çŸ¥é“ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªâ€˜/â€™æ˜¯æ ¹èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼ŒWindowsæ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿä¸ä¼šè¿™ä¹ˆå†™ï¼Œæ˜¯ä»¥ç›˜ç¬¦å¼€å¤´çš„ï¼ˆC:/ç­‰ï¼‰ã€‚å…¶å®Windowsç³»ç»Ÿè¿™ä¹ˆå†™æ˜¯çœç•¥äº†æ ¹èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œå®ƒä¹Ÿå­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªæ ¹èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œå®ƒçš„å­èŠ‚ç‚¹å°±æ˜¯è®¸å¤šçš„ç›˜ç¬¦ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å‡ºäºä¾¿äºé˜…è¯»ç­‰å„ç§åŸå› å°±æŠŠæ ¹èŠ‚ç‚¹çœç•¥äº†ã€‚

å¦‚æœæƒ³è¯·æ±‚authoræ ‡ç­¾åŒ…è£¹çš„æ‰€æœ‰ nickæ ‡ç­¾ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä»å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨XPathï¼š/book/author/nickå°±å¯ä»¥è¯·æ±‚åˆ°è¿™ä¸ªè·¯å¾„ä¸Šçš„æ‰€æœ‰nickæ ‡ç­¾äº†ã€‚è¿™å’Œæ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿä¹Ÿè®¸æœ‰æ‰€ä¸åŒï¼Œæ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿåœ¨åŒä¸€ç›®å½•ä¸‹æ˜¯ä¸å…è®¸å‡ºç°é‡åçš„ï¼Œè€Œç½‘é¡µä¸­å¯ä»¥å‡ºç°å¾ˆå¤šåŒæ ·çš„æ ‡ç­¾ã€‚

python result = tree.xpath("/book/author/nick")

è¿™æ—¶å¯ä»¥æ‰“å°æˆ‘ä»¬çš„resultå‘ç°å®ƒåªæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç±»ä¼¼è¿­ä»£å™¨çš„ç»“æœï¼Œè¿”å›ç»“æœæ˜¯æ‰¾åˆ°xxxæ ‡ç­¾åœ¨xxxåœ°å€ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬å®é™…æƒ³è¦çš„æ˜¯å®ƒæ‰€åŒ…è£¹çš„æ–‡æœ¬å†…å®¹æˆ–è€…å±æ€§å€¼ç­‰æœ‰æ•ˆä¿¡æ¯ ï¼Œè¿™æ€ä¹ˆè·å–çš„ï¼Ÿç›´æ¥/textçš„è¯æ‹¿åˆ°çš„æ˜¯å®ƒä¸‹é¢textæ ‡ç­¾æ‰€åœ¨ä½ç½®ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥è¿™æ—¶è¦text()æ¥å‡ºé©¬äº†ï¼Œå®ƒçš„ä½œç”¨å°±æ˜¯è·å–æŸ¥æ‰¾åˆ°æ ‡ç­¾æ‰€åŒ…è£¹çš„æ–‡æœ¬å†…å®¹ã€‚

python result = tree.xpath("/book/name/text()") # text() æ‹¿æ–‡æœ¬ # è¿”å›ç»“æœï¼š['é‡èŠ±éåœ°é¦™']

ç±»ä¼¼åœ°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥è·å–/book/author/nickä¸‹çš„æ‰€æœ‰äººåï¼š

python result = tree.xpath("/book/author/nick/text()") # è¿”å›ç»“æœï¼š['å‘¨å¤§å¼º', 'å‘¨èŠ·è‹¥', 'å‘¨æ°ä¼¦', 'è”¡ä¾æ—']

ä½†æ˜¯é—®é¢˜æ¥äº†ï¼Œå¦‚æœæˆ‘æƒ³æ‹¿åˆ°authoræ ‡ç­¾é‡Œé¢æ‰€æœ‰nickæ ‡ç­¾åŒ…è£¹çš„æ‰€æœ‰æ–‡å­— æ€ä¹ˆåŠï¼ŸåŒ…æ‹¬çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­1ï¼Œçƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­2ï¼Œçƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­3ï¼Ÿå…ˆçœ‹ä»£ç å†è§£é‡Šï¼š

python result = tree.xpath("/book/author//nick/text()") # // åä»£ # è¿”å›ç»“æœï¼š['å‘¨å¤§å¼º', 'å‘¨èŠ·è‹¥', 'å‘¨æ°ä¼¦', 'è”¡ä¾æ—', 'çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­1', 'çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­2', 'çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­3']

å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨authorååŠ äº†åŒæ–œæ â€™//â€˜ï¼Œå®ƒçš„å«ä¹‰æ˜¯è·å–æ‰€æœ‰åä»£çš„nickæ ‡ç­¾ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¿™ä¿©æ–œæ ä¸­é—´å¯ä»¥æœ‰0å±‚ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥æœ‰1ï¼Œ2ï¼Œ3ï¼Œâ€¦ï¼Œnå±‚ï¼Œåªè¦æ˜¯åœ¨authorä¸‹çš„nickæ ‡ç­¾å°±å…¨éƒ¨è¢«æŠ“å‡ºæ¥äº†ã€‚é‚£ä¹ˆå†è·å–text()å°±å¯ä»¥æŠŠ/book/author/div/nickå’Œ/book/author/span/nickå’Œ/book/author/span/div/nickä¸‰ä¸ªè·¯å¾„ä¸‹çš„æ–‡æœ¬éƒ½æ‹¿åˆ°äº†ã€‚

å®é™…æ“ä½œä¸­æˆ‘ä»¬å¯èƒ½ä¹Ÿä¸éœ€è¦è¿™ä¹ˆå¤šå±‚éƒ½æ‹¿åˆ°ã€‚å¯èƒ½åªéœ€è¦ä¸€å±‚çš„ç»“æœ ï¼Œåˆè¯¥æ€ä¹ˆå¤„ç†ï¼Ÿ

python result = tree.xpath("/book/author/*/nick/text()") # * æ˜¯ä»»æ„çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹. é€šé…ç¬¦ # è¿”å›ç»“æœï¼š['çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­1', 'çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­2']

å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°ï¼Œå®ƒè·å–äº†/book/author/div/nickå’Œ/book/author/span/nickçš„å†…å®¹ï¼Œauthorå’Œnickä¸­é—´çš„ * æ˜Ÿå·è¡¨ç¤ºä»»æ„ç¬¦å·ï¼ˆå³é€šé…ç¬¦ï¼‰ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ä»£æ›¿å„ç§æ ‡ç­¾åï¼Œä½†æ˜¯åªèƒ½æ›¿ä»£ä¸€å±‚ ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æ²¡æœ‰æŠŠä¸‹ä¸€å±‚çš„/book/author/span/div/nickæ‰€åŒ…è£¹çš„çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­3æ‹¿å‡ºæ¥ã€‚

å†ç»ƒä¹ ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼ŒæŠŠè¿™æ®µxmlé‡Œé¢æ‰€æœ‰nickåŒ…è£¹çš„æ–‡æœ¬ å…¨ç»™æˆ‘æ‹¿å‡ºæ¥ï¼

XML result = tree.xpath("/book//nick/text()") è¿”å›ç»“æœï¼š['è‡­è±†è…', 'å‘¨å¤§å¼º', 'å‘¨èŠ·è‹¥', 'å‘¨æ°ä¼¦', 'è”¡ä¾æ—', 'çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­1', 'çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­2', 'çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­3', 'èƒ–èƒ–é™ˆ', 'èƒ–èƒ–ä¸é™ˆ']

ç®€å•å¾—å¾ˆï¼Œåªéœ€è¦åœ¨bookä¸‹é¢åŠ åŒæ–œæ å°±å¥½ã€‚

æµ‹è¯•å®Œæ•´ä»£ç 

æµ‹è¯•çš„æ—¶å€™è¦æŠŠä¸å¿…è¦çš„ä»£ç åŠ æ³¨é‡Šï¼Œè¿™æ ·å¯ä»¥æ–¹ä¾¿çš„æŸ¥çœ‹è¿è¡Œç»“æœï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡debugçœ‹ç»“æœã€‚

ç»™ä»£ç è¡ŒåŠ æ³¨é‡Šåœ¨PyCharmä¸­æœ‰ä¸ªå¿«æ·é”®ï¼šctrl+/ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç»™é€‰ä¸­çš„ä»£ç è¡ŒåŠ æ³¨é‡Šï¼Œå¾ˆæ–¹ä¾¿ã€‚

XML # Created at UESTC # Author: Vector Kun # Time: 2023/1/2 14:16 # xpath æ˜¯åœ¨XMLæ–‡æ¡£ä¸­æœç´¢å†…å®¹çš„ä¸€é—¨è¯­è¨€ # htmlæ˜¯xmlçš„ä¸€ä¸ªå­é›† """ <book> <id>1</id> <name>é‡èŠ±éåœ°é¦™</name> <price>1.23</price> <author> <nick>å‘¨å¤§å¼º</nick> <nick>å‘¨èŠ·è‹¥</nick> </author> </book> """ # å®‰è£…lxmlæ¨¡å— # pip install lxml -i xxxxxx # xpathè§£æ from lxml import etree xml = """ <book> <id>1</id> <name>é‡èŠ±éåœ°é¦™</name> <price>1.23</price> <nick>è‡­è±†è…</nick> <author> <nick id="10086">å‘¨å¤§å¼º</nick> <nick id="10010">å‘¨èŠ·è‹¥</nick> <nick class="jay">å‘¨æ°ä¼¦</nick> <nick class="jolin">è”¡ä¾æ—</nick> <div> <nick>çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­1</nick> </div> <span> <nick>çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­2</nick> <div> <nick>çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­çƒ­3</nick> </div> </span> </author> <partner> <nick id="ppc">èƒ–èƒ–é™ˆ</nick> <nick id="ppbc">èƒ–èƒ–ä¸é™ˆ</nick> </partner> </book> """ tree = etree.XML(xml) # result = tree.xpath("/book") # /è¡¨ç¤ºå±‚çº§å…³ç³». ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª/æ˜¯æ ¹èŠ‚ç‚¹ # result = tree.xpath("/book/name") # result = tree.xpath("/book/name/text()") # text() æ‹¿æ–‡æœ¬ # result = tree.xpath("/book/author//nick/text()") # // åä»£ # result = tree.xpath("/book/author/*/nick/text()") # * æ˜¯ä»»æ„çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹. é€šé…ç¬¦ result = tree.xpath("/book//nick/text()") print(result)

XPathè¿›é˜¶ç”¨æ³•

æˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªç®€å•çš„htmlæ–‡ä»¶æ¥è®²XPathè¿˜å¯ä»¥ç”¨æ¥å¹²ä»€ä¹ˆï¼š

html <!DOCTYPE html> <html lang="en"> <head> <meta charset="UTF-8" /> <title>Title</title> </head> <body> <ul> <li><a href="http://www.baidu.com">ç™¾åº¦</a></li> <li><a href="http://www.google.com">è°·æ­Œ</a></li> <li><a href="http://www.sogou.com">æœç‹—</a></li> </ul> <ol> <li><a href="feiji">é£æœº</a></li> <li><a href="dapao">å¤§ç‚®</a></li> <li><a href="huoche">ç«è½¦</a></li> </ol> <div class="job">æå˜‰è¯š</div> <div class="common">èƒ¡è¾£æ±¤</div> </body> </html>

æ”¾åœ¨pyæ–‡ä»¶åŒçº§æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ï¼Œå‘½åä¸º7_xpath_eg.htmlï¼Œå½“ç„¶å¯ä»¥è‡ªå·±ä¿®æ”¹æ–‡ä»¶åå’Œä»£ç éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚

éœ€æ±‚1ï¼šè®©xpathå¤„ç†è¿™ä¸ªèµ„æºæ–‡ä»¶

python from lxml import etree tree = etree.parse("7_xpath_eg.html")

è¿™ä¸ªæ—¶å€™æˆ‘ä»¬å°±ç”¨åˆ°äº†parseè¿™ä¸ªå‡½æ•°ï¼Œæ¥å¤„ç†æˆ‘ä»¬æœ¬åœ°çš„èµ„æºæ–‡ä»¶ã€‚

éœ€æ±‚2ï¼šæ‰¾åˆ°æ ‡ç­¾ä½ç½®ï¼Œå¦‚htmlæ ‡ç­¾

python result = tree.xpath('/html') # è¿è¡Œç»“æœï¼š[<Element html at 0x15d667f6580>]

å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°æ‰¾åˆ°äº†æ ‡ç­¾ä½ç½®ï¼Œå¹¶æŒ‡å‡ºæ‰€åœ¨åœ°å€ã€‚

éœ€æ±‚3ï¼šæ‰¾åˆ°æ— åºåˆ—è¡¨(ul)ä¸­æ¯ä¸€é¡¹(li)åŒ…è£¹çš„æ–‡æœ¬å†…å®¹

python result = tree.xpath("/html/body/ul/li/a/text()") # è¿è¡Œç»“æœï¼š['ç™¾åº¦', 'è°·æ­Œ', 'æœç‹—']

éœ€æ±‚4ï¼šæ‰¾åˆ°æ— åºåˆ—è¡¨(ul)ä¸­ç¬¬ä¸€é¡¹(li)åŒ…è£¹çš„æ–‡æœ¬å†…å®¹

python result = tree.xpath("/html/body/ul/li[1]/a/text()") # xpathçš„é¡ºåºæ˜¯ä»1å¼€å§‹æ•°çš„, []è¡¨ç¤ºç´¢å¼• # è¿è¡Œç»“æœï¼š['ç™¾åº¦']

è¿™é‡Œæœ‰ç‚¹â€œå¤§é€†ä¸é“â€äº†ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰ä»0å¼€å§‹æ•°ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯1å°±æ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€é¡¹ï¼Œè¿™ä¸€ç‚¹è¦æ³¨æ„ä¸€ä¸‹ã€‚

éœ€æ±‚5ï¼šæ‰¾åˆ°æ— åºåˆ—è¡¨(ul)ä¸­æ¯ä¸€é¡¹(li)åŒ…è£¹çš„é“¾æ¥(a)å†…å®¹

python result = tree.xpath("/html/body/ul/li/a/@href") # è¿è¡Œç»“æœï¼š['http://www.baidu.com', 'http://www.google.com', 'http://www.sogou.com']

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ç”¨â€œ@å±æ€§â€çš„æ–¹æ³•æ¥è·å–å±æ€§å¯¹åº”çš„å±æ€§å€¼

éœ€æ±‚6ï¼šè·å–hrefä¸ºâ€˜dapaoâ€™åŒ…è£¹çš„æ–‡å­—ï¼ˆå±æ€§ç­›é€‰ï¼‰

python result = tree.xpath("/html/body/ol/li/a[@href='dapao']/text()") # [@xxx=xxx] å±æ€§çš„ç­›é€‰ # è¿”å›ç»“æœ['å¤§ç‚®']

ç­›é€‰å±æ€§å¯ä»¥åœ¨æ‰€å±æ ‡ç­¾ååŠ [@xxxå±æ€§=xxxå±æ€§å€¼]ç­›é€‰å‡ºå«å¯¹åº”å±æ€§å€¼çš„æ ‡ç­¾ä½ç½®ï¼Œè¿™ä¸€ç‚¹å¾ˆåƒbs4çš„æ€è·¯ã€‚

éœ€æ±‚7ï¼šå…ˆè·å–åˆ—è¡¨é¡¹ï¼Œå†é€’å½’æ¯ä¸ªåˆ—è¡¨é¡¹å–å‡ºåŒ…è£¹æ–‡æœ¬å’Œaæ ‡ç­¾çš„hrefå±æ€§å€¼

python ol_li_list = tree.xpath("/html/body/ol/li") for li in ol_li_list: # ä»æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªliä¸­æå–åˆ°æ–‡å­—ä¿¡æ¯ result = li.xpath("./a/text()") # åœ¨liä¸­ç»§ç»­å»å¯»æ‰¾. ç›¸å¯¹æŸ¥æ‰¾ print(result) result2 = li.xpath("./a/@href") # æ‹¿åˆ°å±æ€§å€¼: @å±æ€§ print(result2)

./ç›¸ä¿¡å¤§å®¶æ¯”è¾ƒç†Ÿæ‚‰ï¼Œå®ƒçš„æ„ä¹‰å°±æ˜¯ä»¥å½“å‰è·¯å¾„è¿›è¡Œç›¸å¯¹æŸ¥æ‰¾ï¼Œâ€™.â€™å°±ä»£è¡¨/html/body/ol/liã€‚

entry.title: HTML and XHTML
entry.content:
Table of Contents

XHTML Introduction

What is XHTML?

Why Use XHTML?

Document Structure

Element Syntax

Attribute Syntax

How to Convert from HTML to XHTML

XHTML Elements

XHTML Attributes

XHTML Introduction

XHTML is HTML written as XML.

What is XHTML?

  • XHTML stands for EXtensible HyperText Markup Language
  • XHTML is almost identical to HTML 4.01
  • XHTML is a stricter and cleaner version of HTML
  • XHTML is HTML defined as an XML application
  • XHTML is a W3C Recommendation from January 2001
  • XHTML is supported by all major browsers

Why Use XHTML?

Many pages on the internet contain â€œbadâ€ HTML.

XML is a markup language where documents must be marked up correctly and be â€œwell-formedâ€.

By combining the strengths of HTML and XML, XHTML was developed. XHTML is HTML redesigned as XML.

Document Structure

  • XHTML DOCTYPE is mandatory
  • The xmlns attribute in <html> is mandatory
  • <html>, <head>, <title>, and <body> are mandatory

Element Syntax

  • XHTML elements must be properly nested
  • XHTML elements must always be closed
  • XHTML elements must be in lowercase
  • XHTML documents must have one root element

Attribute Syntax

  • XHTML attributes must be in lowercase
  • XHTML attribute values must be quoted
  • XHTML attribute minimization is forbidden

How to Convert from HTML to XHTML

  1. Add an XHTML <!DOCTYPE> to the first line of every page
  2. Add an xmlns attribute to the html element of every page
  3. Change all element names to lowercase
  4. Close all empty elements
  5. Change all attribute names to lowercase
  6. Quote all attribute values

XHTML Elements

XHTML Elements Must Be Properly Nested

Wrong:

Correct:

XHTML Elements Must Always Be Closed

Wrong:

Correct:

Empty Elements Must Also Be Closed

Wrong:

Correct:

XHTML Elements Must Be Lowercase

Wrong:

Correct:

XHTML Attributes

XHTML Attributes Must Be Lowercase

Wrong:

Correct:

XHTML Attribute Values Must Be Quoted

Wrong:

Correct:

Attribute Minimization Is Forbidden

Wrong:

Correct:

entry.title: 09. bs4 Parsing Basics and Examples
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 09. bs4 Parsing Basics and Examples
ğŸ“Š 802 views | ğŸ‘ 4 likes | ğŸ’¬ 4 comments | â­ 6 favorites

Table of Contents

Introduction

Installing bs4

bs4 Usage Basics

bs4 Example: Scraping Vegetable Prices

Code Implementation

Complete Code

Important Reminder

Summary

Introduction

We now have basic HTML knowledge and can identify various elements in HTML source code. In this chapter, weâ€™ll formally learn bs4 usage and demonstrate its convenience with an example. Compared to regex, bs4 is much simpler.

Installing bs4

If you havenâ€™t installed Python modules before, refer to my requests chapter on module installation - just replace â€œrequestsâ€ with â€œbs4â€.

For most readers at this point, you should already know how to install modules. Install bs4 as follows:

bs4 Usage Basics

BeautifulSoup objects retrieve HTML content mainly through two methods:

  • find()
  • find_all()

Whether using find or find_all, the parameters are almost identical:

  • Syntax: find(tag, attribute=value) means searching for xxx tag in the page where the xxx attribute must be xxx value

For example, find('div', age=18) means finding a div tag in the page where the attribute age must be 18.

find_all() usage is almost identical to find(). find() finds one, find_all() finds all on the page.

bs4 Example: Scraping Vegetable Prices

As we know, as long as data exists in the source code, we can easily find and extract it with bs4.

Objective: Scrape a vegetable price table from a website and save all information to a CSV file.

Code Implementation

Step one, as usual, get the source code first:

Step two, pass the entire page source code to BeautifulSoup for preprocessing. Then we can access all HTML tags through the bs object.

Step three, locate the vegetable price table we want:

We use the find function. The two most commonly used are: find (finds one) and find_all (finds all).

In the source code, we can see all the vegetable price data is wrapped in <table> tags, meaning itâ€™s in a table. Tables consist of <tr> and <td> - rows and columns.

The approach is clear: first locate the table, then get all rows, then save data from each row to the CSV file.

First, check the source code to locate the table:

We can see the table tag has an attribute value that appears for the first time, so we can precisely find it with find:

Next, locate all rows:

Since the table has a header, we can slice from index 1 to skip it.

Finally, iterate through all rows and extract the data:

This successfully writes data to the file. Remember to close the file and network request - itâ€™s a good habit to maintain.

Complete Code

Important Reminder

As you can see, this website has over 10,000 pages. As beginners, donâ€™t blindly scrape all the data! First, itâ€™s not very useful. Second, it puts a heavy load on the website server - essentially causing damage. So take it easy and just try a few pages for practice! You can also modify the URL in the source code or add a for loop for automatic pagination.

Summary

Today we learned bs4 parsing and practiced with an example, scraping vegetable prices from a website. bs4 is clearly simpler and more convenient than regex. Remember not to access websites at high frequency - thatâ€™s similar to a DDoS attack and very unfriendly to website servers.

entry.title: 10. Supplementary Example: Scraping Dynamic JS Vegetable Price Pages
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 10. Supplementary Example: Scraping Dynamic JS Vegetable Price Pages
ğŸ“Š 301 views | ğŸ‘ 4 likes | ğŸ’¬ 2 comments | â­ 5 favorites

Table of Contents

Introduction

Approach

Code Implementation

Complete Code

Summary

Introduction

A typical case for scraping vegetable prices is a Beijing wholesale market website, but its page has been redesigned and canâ€™t be scraped using bs4 parsing. Through analysis, we found it uses dynamic JS requests for the table, so weâ€™ll tackle it accordingly.

Approach

  1. First observe the source code - the data isnâ€™t in the source code

  1. Open the web debugger (F12), select the Network tab, and record network activity. When we change pages, we can detect a dynamic JS request:

After clicking to change pages, the following request appears:

Checking the details, we find itâ€™s a POST request:

Looking at its payload - the parameters that need to be passed:

We find seven data items in the parameters. The most important are the first two: the limit of items per transmission and the current page number.

Opening the URL also shows the data exists:

So we can use requests to access this URL.

Code Implementation

Step one, our old friend - get the source code first:

Here dat is our required parameter dictionary.

Step two, calculate the number of pages:

Step three, write to CSV file. We wonâ€™t scrape more here - try it yourself if you want:

As always, remember to close the file and request port at the end.

Complete Code

Summary

Today we supplemented with a Beijing wholesale market vegetable price scraping method, â€œcrackingâ€ their attempt to block our data scraping through dynamic JS requests. Itâ€™s relatively simple. Keep up the good work and letâ€™s continue learning together!

è¿™ä¸‹æ€è·¯å°±æ˜ç¡®äº†ï¼šå…ˆå®šä½åˆ°è¡¨æ ¼ï¼Œå†è·å¾—æ‰€æœ‰è¡Œï¼Œå†æŠŠæ‰€æœ‰è¡Œä¸­çš„æ•°æ®ä¾æ¬¡å­˜å…¥csvæ–‡ä»¶ã€‚

é¦–å…ˆæŸ¥çœ‹æºä»£ç ï¼Œå®šä½è¡¨æ ¼ï¼š

å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°è¡¨æ ¼æ ‡ç­¾ä¸­æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå±æ€§å€¼ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”æ˜¯é¦–æ¬¡å‡ºç°ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆæˆ‘ä»¬å°±å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡findç²¾å‡†çš„æŠŠä»–æ‰¾å‡ºæ¥

python # 2. ä»bså¯¹è±¡ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾æ•°æ® # find(æ ‡ç­¾, å±æ€§=å€¼)ï¼šæ‰¾ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª # find_all(æ ‡ç­¾, å±æ€§=å€¼)ï¼šæ‰¾å…¨éƒ¨ # table = page.find("table",class_="price-table") # classæ˜¯pythonä¸­çš„å…³é”®å­—ï¼ŒåŠ _ä»¥ç¤ºåŒºåˆ« # å¦ä¸€ç§å†™æ³•ï¼š table = page.find("table", attrs={"class": "price-table"}) # å’Œä¸Šä¸€è¡Œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ„æ€ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶å¯ä»¥é¿å…class # print(table)

ä¸‹ä¸€æ­¥ï¼Œå®šä½æ‰€æœ‰è¡Œ

python # ä¸æƒ³è¦åˆ—åé‚£ä¸€è¡Œï¼ˆè¡¨å¤´ï¼‰ï¼Œåªæƒ³è¦åº•ä¸‹çš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œå³æ‹¿åˆ°æ‰€æœ‰æ•°æ®è¡Œ trs = table.find_all("tr")[1:] # træ˜¯è¡Œçš„æ„æ€

å› ä¸ºè¡¨æ ¼è¿˜å­˜åœ¨è¡¨å¤´ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¸æƒ³è¦çš„è¯å°±å¯ä»¥ä»ç¬¬ä¸€è¡Œå¼€å§‹åˆ‡ç‰‡ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å°±ä¸ä¼šæ‹¿åˆ°è¡¨å¤´äº†ã€‚

è¿™æ ·æˆ‘ä»¬å°±é¡ºåˆ©çš„æŠŠæ•°æ®å†™å…¥æ–‡ä»¶äº†ã€‚ä¸€å®šè¦è®°å¾—è¦å…³é—­æ–‡ä»¶å¹¶ä¸”å…³é—­ç½‘ç»œè¯·æ±‚ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½ä¹ æƒ¯ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›å¤§å®¶ä¿æŒã€‚

python # å®‰è£… # pip install bs4 -i æ¸…å # 1. æ‹¿åˆ°é¡µé¢æºä»£ç  # 2. ä½¿ç”¨bs4è¿›è¡Œè§£æ. æ‹¿åˆ°æ•°æ® import requests from bs4 import BeautifulSoup import csv # æ‹¿åˆ°é¡µé¢æºä»£ç  url = "åœ¨è¯„è®ºåŒº" resp = requests.get(url) # print(resp.text) f = open("å¹¿å·æ±Ÿå—èœä»·.csv", mode="w", newline="", encoding="utf-8") csvwriter = csv.writer(f) # ä½¿ç”¨bs4è§£ææ•°æ®ï¼ˆä¸¤æ­¥ï¼‰ # 1. ç”Ÿæˆbså¯¹è±¡ page = BeautifulSoup(resp.text, "html.parser") # æŒ‡å®šhtmlè§£æå™¨ # 2. ä»bså¯¹è±¡ä¸­æŸ¥æ‰¾æ•°æ® # find(æ ‡ç­¾, å±æ€§=å€¼)ï¼šæ‰¾ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ª # find_all(æ ‡ç­¾, å±æ€§=å€¼)ï¼šæ‰¾å…¨éƒ¨ # table = page.find("table",class_="price-table") # classæ˜¯pythonä¸­çš„å…³é”®å­—ï¼ŒåŠ _ä»¥ç¤ºåŒºåˆ« # å¦ä¸€ç§å†™æ³•ï¼š table = page.find("table", attrs={"class": "price-table"}) # å’Œä¸Šä¸€è¡Œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ„æ€ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶å¯ä»¥é¿å…class # print(table) # ä¸æƒ³è¦åˆ—åé‚£ä¸€è¡Œï¼ˆè¡¨å¤´ï¼‰ï¼Œåªæƒ³è¦åº•ä¸‹çš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œå³æ‹¿åˆ°æ‰€æœ‰æ•°æ®è¡Œ trs = table.find_all("tr")[1:] # træ˜¯è¡Œçš„æ„æ€ for tr in trs: # æ¯ä¸€è¡Œ tds = tr.find_all("td") # tdè¡¨ç¤ºå•å…ƒæ ¼ã€‚æ‹¿åˆ°æ¯è¡Œä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰td # print(tds[0]) # åå­—ã€äº§åœ°ã€å‡ä»·ï¼ˆå…ƒ/å…¬æ–¤ï¼‰ã€è§„æ ¼ã€æ—¥æœŸ name = tds[0].text # .textè¡¨ç¤ºæ‹¿åˆ°è¢«æ ‡ç­¾æ ‡è®°çš„å†…å®¹ place = tds[1].text avg_price = tds[2].text spec = tds[3].text date = tds[4].text # print(name,place,avg_price,spec,date) csvwriter.writerow([name, place, avg_price, spec, date]) f.close() print("over!!!") resp.close()

é‡è¦æé†’

å¤§å®¶å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°æœ¬ä¾‹æ¶‰åŠçš„ç½‘ç«™ä¸€å…±æœ‰ä¸€ä¸‡å¤šé¡µï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½œä¸ºåˆå­¦è€…ä¸€å®šä¸è¦ç›²ç›®çš„å»æŠŠæ‰€æœ‰æ•°æ®éƒ½æ‰’æ‹¿åˆ°ï¼ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆç”¨å¤„ï¼Œå†ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¯å¯¹ç½‘ç«™æœåŠ¡å™¨çš„è´Ÿæ‹…å¾ˆå¤§ï¼Œç›¸å½“äºæç ´åäº†ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¤§å®¶è¿˜æ˜¯æ‚ ç€ç‚¹ï¼Œé€‚é‡çš„å»è¯•å‡ é¡µç»ƒæ‰‹å°±å¥½ï¼å½“ç„¶ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ä¿®æ”¹æºä»£ç é‡Œé¢çš„urléƒ¨åˆ†æˆ–è€…å¥—ä¸€ä¸ªforå¾ªç¯æ¥è‡ªåŠ¨è¿›è¡Œæ¢é¡µçˆ¬å–ã€‚

æ€»ç»“

entry.content:
æœ¬æ–‡è¿ç§»è‡ªCSDNåšå®¢

çˆ¬å–èœä»·çš„å…¸å‹æ¡ˆä¾‹æ˜¯åŒ—äº¬æ–°XXç½‘ç«™ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å®ƒé¡µé¢å·²ç»æ”¹ç‰ˆï¼Œæ— æ³•é€šè¿‡bs4è§£ææ–¹å¼è¿›è¡Œçˆ¬å–ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬é€šè¿‡åˆ†æå‘ç°å®ƒæ˜¯é€šè¿‡jsåŠ¨æ€è¯·æ±‚è¡¨æ ¼çš„ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä»¬å†æ¬¡å¯¹å®ƒè§æ‹›æ‹†æ‹›ã€‚

æ€è·¯

1. å…ˆè§‚å¯Ÿæºä»£ç ï¼Œå‘ç°æ•°æ®ä¸åœ¨æºä»£ç ä¸­

2. æ‰“å¼€ç½‘é¡µè°ƒè¯•å™¨ï¼ˆF12ï¼‰ï¼Œé€‰æ‹©Networké€‰é¡¹ï¼Œè®°å½•ç½‘ç»œæ´»åŠ¨ã€‚å½“æˆ‘ä»¬æ¢é¡µçš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œèƒ½æ£€æµ‹åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªåŠ¨æ€çš„jsè¯·æ±‚ï¼š

ç‚¹å‡»æ¢é¡µä»¥åå‡ºç°ä»¥ä¸‹è¯·æ±‚ï¼š

æˆ‘ä»¬æŸ¥çœ‹è¯¦æƒ…ï¼Œå‘ç°å®ƒæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªPOSTè¯·æ±‚

æŸ¥çœ‹å…¶è´Ÿè½½ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯æ‰€éœ€è¦ä¼ é€’çš„å‚æ•°ï¼š

å‘ç°æˆ‘ä»¬ä¼ å‚é‡Œæœ‰ä¸Šè¿°ä¸ƒä¸ªæ•°æ®ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­æœ€é‡è¦çš„å°±æ˜¯å‰ä¸¤ä¸ªï¼šåˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯é™åˆ¶æ¯æ¬¡ä¼ è¾“çš„ä¿¡æ¯æ¡æ•°å’Œå½“å‰é¡µé¢ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯ç¬¬currenté¡µã€‚

æ‰“å¼€URLä¹Ÿèƒ½çœ‹åˆ°é‡Œé¢ç¡®å®å­˜åœ¨æ•°æ®ï¼š

æ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥è€ƒè™‘ç”¨requestsæ¥è®¿é—®è¯¥URL

ä»£ç å®ç°

ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥ï¼Œè€æœ‹å‹ï¼Œå…ˆè·å–æºä»£ç 

python url = 'åœ¨è¯„è®ºåŒº' dat = { "limit": "", "current": "", "pubDateStartTime": "", "pubDateEndTime": "", "prodPcatid": "", "prodCatid": "", "prodName": "" } resp = requests.post(url, data=dat) # print(resp.json())

å…¶ä¸­datæ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„å‚æ•°å­—å…¸ã€‚

ç¬¬äºŒæ­¥ï¼Œè®¡ç®—å‡ºé¡µæ•°ç­‰

python all_count = int(resp.json()["count"]) limit = int(resp.json()["limit"]) all_page_number = int(all_count / limit)

ç¬¬ä¸‰æ­¥ï¼Œå†™å…¥csvæ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œå°±ä¸çˆ¬å–æ›´å¤šäº†ï¼Œå¦‚æœæƒ³çš„è¯å°±è‡ªå·±è¯•è¯•çœ‹~

å®Œæ•´ä»£ç

entry.title: 07. Practical: Scraping Movie Torrent Links with Python Regex
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 07. Practical: Scraping Movie Torrent Links with Python Regex
ğŸ“Š 1251 views | ğŸ‘ 3 likes | ğŸ’¬ 2 comments | â­ 8 favorites

Table of Contents

Introduction

Objective

Approach

Code Implementation

Step 1: Import Libraries

Step 2: Request Source Code

Step 3: Debug Step 2

Step 4: Locate Information with Regex

Step 5: Access and Extract Sub-page Content

Complete Code

Results

Summary

Introduction

In the previous chapter, we covered scraping movie Top 250 information with Python regex. This chapter presents another simple regex scraping example: extracting torrent resources from a movie website!

Objective

Extract movie names and corresponding torrent links from a â€œ2022 Must-Watch Moviesâ€ list on a website.

Approach

  1. Locate the 2022 Must-Watch Movies section
  2. Extract sub-page links from the list
  3. Request sub-page links to get the download addresses we want

Code Implementation

Step 1: Import Libraries

Quick review: the re library is for Regular Expressions - Pythonâ€™s regex library for data parsing. The requests library is what we use to make web requests.

Step 2: Request Source Code

Two potential issues here:

  1. If resp throws an error, it might be an HTTPS issue. The difference between https and http is security verification. If we get an error accessing an https page, add verify=False to requests.get() to skip security verification.

  2. When printing the source code, Chinese characters might appear garbled. This is definitely an encoding issue! HTMLâ€™s default encoding matches PyCharmâ€™s - both use UTF-8. But when garbled text appears, we need to find out how this webpageâ€™s encoding differs.

Step 3: Debug Step 2

  1. Modify the resp line:
  1. Observe the webpage source code header tag which specifies the encoding:

<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=gb2312"> shows charset=gb2312, so we should use gb2312 encoding.

Now printing the source code wonâ€™t show garbled text.

Step 4: Locate Information with Regex

  1. First check the page source code to locate elements:

We can observe that starting from <ul>, each <li> contains the resource name and link we need.

Note: <ul> represents an unordered list, and each <li> represents a list item; <div> is a block-level element indicating this section is a whole unit.

  1. Use regex to locate the above source code:

We use lazy matching to extract the information wrapped in <li> tags. Itâ€™s quite accurate, but we canâ€™t use it directly - we need to refine it and extract the specific details.

  1. Apply regex again to get the desired information:

The <a> tag represents a hyperlink, and the href attribute references the sub-link, which is a path added to the current domain to locate what we need. So we concatenate the domain from our earlier code with the sub-page address.

When printed, we find an extra slash in the link. We use the strip function to remove it, then recursively save to the list.

Step 5: Access and Extract Sub-page Content

The information we need appears starting from line 90 in the source code, as shown.

Based on the known information, we write the regex expression, preprocess it, and get the movie name and torrent link.

Then we iterate through all links in the sub-page list to get all the 2022 must-watch movie names and torrents.

Complete Code

Results

As you can see, both movie names and torrent links were successfully extracted. Done!

Summary

Today we used regex to scrape 2022 must-watch movie names and their torrent download links, further practicing the use of the re module. Next chapter, weâ€™ll briefly introduce HTML syntax to prepare for learning bs4 and xpath later.

entry.title: 08. Preparation for bs4 Parsing: Understanding HTML Basics
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 08. Preparation for bs4 Parsing: Understanding HTML Basics
ğŸ“Š 154 views | ğŸ‘ 2 likes | ğŸ’¬ 1 comment | â­ 3 favorites

Table of Contents

Introduction

Purpose

HTML Basics

  1. Systematic HTML Learning

  2. Quick Overview

Introduction

This series will cover three parsing methods: regex, bs4, and xpath. Weâ€™ve already learned regex parsing and built two practical projects, basically mastering this parsing method.

When learning regex parsing, we also learned some essential basics like regular expressions. Before learning other parsing methods, we must face a practical issue: understanding HTML source code.

Purpose

Why learn HTML? As the ancient saying goes, â€œKnow yourself and know your enemy, and you will never be defeated.â€ If we want to scrape data from web pages more effectively and efficiently, we must understand basic HTML syntax. This helps us locate data faster instead of blindly searching through incomprehensible code.

HTML Basics

1. Systematic HTML Learning

If you want to systematically learn HTML basics, my column covers HTML fundamentals in detail, with examples and hands-on practice pages for learning.

2. Quick Overview

HTML syntax is quite simple with high fault tolerance - it will run no matter what. However, code readability is crucial, especially for website maintainers. If a site has issues, messy HTML code is hard to read, making it difficult for administrators to locate problems and for beginners to find data.

So our goal is to understand HTMLâ€™s basic layout:

Now we understand that HTML source code is essentially composed of various tags, each with its own meaning, containing data with corresponding attributes.

ä¸Šä¸€èŠ‚æˆ‘ä»¬è®²åˆ°äº†Pythonæ­£åˆ™æ³•æŠ“å–æŸç”µå½±ç½‘Top250ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œ

è¿™ä¸€èŠ‚å†è¿›è¡Œä¸€ä¸ªç®€å•çš„æ­£åˆ™æ³•æŠ“å–ä¾‹å­ï¼šæŠ“å–æŸç½‘ç«™çš„è¿…é›·ç§å­èµ„æºï¼

ç›®çš„

è·å–æŸç½‘ç«™ä¸­2022å¿…çœ‹ç‰‡æ¦œå•ä¸­æ‰€æœ‰ç”µå½±çš„ç‰‡åä¸å¯¹åº”è¿…é›·ç§å­

æ€è·¯

1. å®šä½åˆ°2022å¿…çœ‹ç‰‡

2. ä»2022å¿…çœ‹ç‰‡ä¸­æå–å­é¡µé¢çš„é“¾æ¥åœ°å€

3. è¯·æ±‚å­é¡µé¢çš„é“¾æ¥åœ°å€ï¼Œæ‹¿åˆ°æˆ‘ä»¬æƒ³è¦çš„ä¸‹è½½åœ°å€

ä»£ç å®ç°

ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥ï¼Œå…ˆå¯¼åŒ…

python import re import requests

å¤ä¹ ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼Œreåº“å°±æ˜¯Regular Expressionï¼Œå³Pythonçš„æ­£åˆ™åº“ï¼Œç”¨äºæ•°æ®åˆ†æã€‚requestsåº“æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬è¯·æ±‚ç½‘é¡µæ‰€ç”¨çš„åº“ã€‚

ç¬¬äºŒæ­¥ï¼Œè¯·æ±‚æºä»£ç 

python domain = "è§è¯„è®ºåŒº" # domainå°±æ˜¯urlï¼Œæ¢äº†ä¸ªè¯´æ³• resp = requests.get(domain) # å¦‚æœæŠ¥é”™ï¼Œå¯èƒ½æ˜¯http's'çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚é‚£ä¹ˆå°±éœ€è¦åŠ ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°' verify = False 'ï¼Œä¸è¿›è¡Œå®‰å…¨æ ¡éªŒ print(resp.text)

è¿™é‡Œå¯èƒ½å‡ºç°ä¸¤ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼š

1. respæŠ¥é”™ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œå¯èƒ½æ˜¯http**â€™sâ€™** çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œhttpså’Œhttpçš„åŒºåˆ«å°±åœ¨äºæ˜¯å¦è¿›è¡Œå®‰å…¨æ ¡éªŒã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬è®¿é—®httpsç½‘é¡µå¦‚æœæŠ¥é”™ï¼Œé‚£å°±åœ¨requests.get()ä¸­æ·»åŠ å‚æ•°verify=Falseï¼Œå°±å¯ä»¥è·³è¿‡å®‰å…¨æ ¡éªŒæ­¥éª¤äº†

2. printç½‘é¡µæºä»£ç æ—¶æˆ‘ä»¬å‘ç°ï¼Œæ¶‰åŠåˆ°ä¸­æ–‡çš„æ—¶å€™æ‰“å°å‡ºäº†ä¹±ç ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªæ—¶å€™æˆ‘ä»¬è¦æ•é”çš„æ„Ÿè§‰åˆ°ä¸€å®šæ˜¯ç¼–ç æ–¹å¼çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼htmlé»˜è®¤çš„ç¼–ç æ–¹å¼å’ŒPyCharmæ˜¯ä¸€è‡´çš„ï¼Œéƒ½æ˜¯UTF-8ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯æ­¤æ—¶å‡ºç°äº†ä¹±ç æˆ‘ä»¬å°±è¦å»å¯»æ‰¾è¿™ä¸ªç½‘é¡µçš„ç¼–ç æ–¹å¼æœ‰ä½•ä¸åŒã€‚

ç¬¬ä¸‰æ­¥ï¼Œdebugç¬¬äºŒæ­¥

1. ä¿®æ”¹respè¡Œå‡½æ•°ä¸º

python resp = requests.get(domain, verify=False)

2. è§‚å¯Ÿå‘ç°ç½‘é¡µæºä»£ç çš„å¤´éƒ¨æ ‡ç­¾ä¸­è§„å®šäº†æ­¤ç½‘é¡µçš„ç¼–ç æ–¹å¼ï¼š

ä¸­charset=gb2312ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä»¬åº”è¯¥é‡‡ç”¨gb2312ç¼–ç ã€‚

æ³¨ï¼šå¦‚æœæƒ³äº†è§£æ›´å¤šå…³äºHTMLå¤´éƒ¨æ ‡ç­¾çš„çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œè¯·è®¿é—®HTMLå¤´éƒ¨

python resp.encoding = 'gb2312' # æŒ‡å®šå­—ç¬¦é›† print(resp.text) resp.close()

æ­¤æ—¶å†æ‰“å°æºä»£ç å°±ä¸ä¼šå‡ºç°ä¹±ç äº†

ç¬¬å››æ­¥ï¼Œæ­£åˆ™æ³•å®šä½ä¿¡æ¯

1. å…ˆæ£€æŸ¥é¡µé¢æºä»£ç å®šä½

å¯ä»¥è§‚å¯Ÿåˆ°ï¼Œä»

    å¼€å§‹ï¼Œæ¯ä¸€ä¸ª
  • ä¸­ åŒ…å«æˆ‘ä»¬å¯¹åº”çš„èµ„æºåç§°å’Œé“¾æ¥ï¼Œè¿™æ­£æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„ã€‚

    å…¶å®ï¼Œ

      æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯æ— åºåˆ—è¡¨ï¼Œè€Œæ¯ä¸€ä¸ª
    • ä»£è¡¨æ— åºåˆ—è¡¨ä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ—è¡¨é¡¹ï¼›
      æ˜¯æµè§ˆå™¨çš„å—çº§å…ƒç´ ï¼Œè¡¨è¾¾è¿™ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ•´ä½“ã€‚å¦‚æœæƒ³äº†è§£æ›´å¤šå…³äºHTMLåˆ—è¡¨å’ŒHTMLå—çº§å…ƒç´ çš„çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œè¯·ç‚¹å‡»ä¸‹é¢çš„è¶…é“¾æ¥

      HTMLåˆ—è¡¨ HTMLå—çº§å…ƒç´ 

      2. æ­£åˆ™æ³•å®šä½ä¸Šè¿°æºä»£ç 

      python # å®šä½æˆåŠŸ obj1 = re.compile(r"2022å¿…çœ‹çƒ­ç‰‡.*?<ul>(?P<ul>.*?)</ul>", re.S) result1 = obj1.finditer(resp.text) for it in result1: ul = it.group('ul') # print(ul)

      æˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜æ˜¯ç”¨æƒ°æ€§æœç´¢æ‹¿å‡ºäº†ä¸­é—´ä¸€å¤§å †

    • åŒ…è£¹çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯å¾ˆå‡†ç¡®çš„ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸èƒ½ç›´æ¥æŠŠè¿™ä¸ªæ‹¿æ¥ç”¨ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è¦è¿›è¡Œé‡å®šä½ï¼ŒæŠŠä¿¡æ¯ç»†èŠ‚æå–å‡ºæ¥ï¼Œä¸è¦å…¶ä½™å¤šä½™çš„ä»£ç 

      3. å†æ¬¡æ­£åˆ™ï¼Œæ‹¿å‡ºæƒ³è¦çš„ä¿¡æ¯

      python # htmlä¸­ï¼Œaæ ‡ç­¾è¡¨ç¤ºè¶…é“¾æ¥ï¼Œç‚¹å‡»å¯¹åº”çš„å¯¹è±¡å°±ä¼šè·³è½¬åˆ°hrefå¼•ç”¨çš„é“¾æ¥ä¸­ï¼Œtitleæ˜¯é¼ æ ‡é€‰ä¸­ä»¥åæµ®ç°å‡ºçš„æç¤ºæ–‡å­—ï¼Œä¸»è¦éœ€è¦hrefä¸­çš„å­é¡µé¢é“¾æ¥ # æå–å­é¡µé¢é“¾æ¥ obj2 = re.compile(r"<a href='(?P<href>.*?)'", re.S) result2 = obj2.finditer(ul) child_href_list = [] for i in result2: href = i.group('href') # æ‹¼æ¥å­é¡µé¢urlåœ°å€ï¼šåŸŸå+å­é¡µé¢åœ°å€ï¼ˆè¿™é‡Œå¤šäº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ–œæ ï¼Œè¦stripæ‰ï¼‰ child_href = domain + href.strip("/") # print(child_href) # ä¸ºäº†æ–¹ä¾¿ï¼ŒæŠŠå®ƒä»¬è£…è¿›åˆ—è¡¨é‡Œ child_href_list.append(child_href) # æŠŠå­é¡µé¢é“¾æ¥ä¿å­˜èµ·æ¥ # 37 + 38 = child_href_list = [child_href] # child_href_list = [child_href]

      è¿™é‡Œæ ‡ç­¾å°±æ˜¯è¡¨ç¤ºè¶…é“¾æ¥ï¼Œherfå…ƒç´ çš„å«ä¹‰å°±æ˜¯å¼•ç”¨å­é“¾æ¥ï¼Œæ˜¯åŸºäºå½“å‰åŸŸåæ·»åŠ è·¯å¾„å®šä½åˆ°æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„ä½ç½®ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦æŠŠä¹‹å‰ä»£ç ä¸­å†™åˆ°çš„åŸŸådomainå’Œå­é¡µé¢åœ°å€æ‹¼æ¥èµ·æ¥ã€‚

      æ‰“å°å‡ºæ¥å‘ç°é“¾æ¥å¤šäº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ–œæ ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨stripå‡½æ•°å»æ‰ï¼Œç„¶åé€’å½’åœ°ä¿å­˜åˆ°åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­å°±å¥½äº†ã€‚

      å…³äºè¶…é“¾æ¥çš„çŸ¥è¯†è¯·è®¿é—®HTMLé“¾æ¥

      ç¬¬äº”æ­¥ï¼Œè®¿é—®æå–å­é¡µé¢å†…å®¹

      æºä»£ç 90è¡Œå¼€å§‹å‡ºç°äº†æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå¦‚å›¾æ‰€ç¤º

      python # æå–å­é¡µé¢å†…å®¹ obj3 = re.compile(r'â—ç‰‡ å(?P<moviename>.*?)<br />.*?<td ' r'style="WORD-WRAP: break-word" bgcolor="#fdfddf"><a href="(?P<download>.*?)">', re.S) for href in child_href_list: child_resp = requests.get(href) child_resp.encoding = 'gb2312' # print(child_resp.text) result3 = obj3.finditer(child_resp.text) for j in result3: moviename = j.group("moviename") download = j.group("download") print(moviename) print(download) # break # æµ‹è¯•ç”¨ child_resp.close()

charset=gb2312">ä¸­charset=gb2312ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥é‡‡ç”¨gb2312ç¼–ç  resp.encoding = 'gb2312' # æŒ‡å®šå­—ç¬¦é›† # print(resp.text) resp.close() # å®šä½æˆåŠŸ obj1 = re.compile(r"2022å¿…çœ‹çƒ­ç‰‡.*?<ul>(?P<ul>.*?)</ul>", re.S) result1 = obj1.finditer(resp.text) for it in result1: ul = it.group('ul') # print(ul) # htmlä¸­ï¼Œaæ ‡ç­¾è¡¨ç¤ºè¶…é“¾æ¥ï¼Œç‚¹å‡»å¯¹åº”çš„å¯¹è±¡å°±ä¼šè·³è½¬åˆ°hrefå¼•ç”¨çš„é“¾æ¥ä¸­ï¼Œtitleæ˜¯é¼ æ ‡é€‰ä¸­ä»¥åæµ®ç°å‡ºçš„æç¤ºæ–‡å­—ï¼Œä¸»è¦éœ€è¦hrefä¸­çš„å­é¡µé¢é“¾æ¥ # æå–å­é¡µé¢é“¾æ¥ obj2 = re.compile(r"<a href='(?P<href>.*?)'", re.S) result2 = obj2.finditer(ul) child_href_list = [] for i in result2: href = i.group('href') # æ‹¼æ¥å­é¡µé¢urlåœ°å€ï¼šåŸŸå+å­é¡µé¢åœ°å€ï¼ˆè¿™é‡Œå¤šäº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ–œæ ï¼Œè¦stripæ‰ï¼‰ child_href = domain + href.strip("/") # print(child_href) # ä¸ºäº†æ–¹ä¾¿ï¼ŒæŠŠå®ƒä»¬è£…è¿›åˆ—è¡¨é‡Œ child_href_list.append(child_href) # æŠŠå­é¡µé¢é“¾æ¥ä¿å­˜èµ·æ¥ # 37 + 38 = child_href_list = [child_href] # child_href_list = [child_href] # æå–å­é¡µé¢å†…å®¹ obj3 = re.compile(r'â—ç‰‡ å(?P<moviename>.*?)<br />.*?<td ' r'style="WORD-WRAP: break-word" bgcolor="#fdfddf"><a href="(?P<download>.*?)">', re.S) for href in child_href_list: child_resp = requests.get(href) child_resp.encoding = 'gb2312' # print(child_resp.text) result3 = obj3.finditer(child_resp.text) for j in result3: moviename = j.group("moviename") download = j.group("download") print(moviename) print(download) # break # æµ‹è¯•ç”¨ child_resp.close()

python # bs4è§£æåŸºç¡€ï¼šHTMLè¯­æ³• # HTML æ˜¯ç”¨æ¥æè¿°ç½‘é¡µçš„ä¸€ç§è¯­è¨€ã€‚ # HTML æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯è¶…æ–‡æœ¬æ ‡è®°è¯­è¨€ (Hyper Text Markup Language) # HTML ä¸æ˜¯ä¸€ç§ç¼–ç¨‹è¯­è¨€ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ä¸€ç§æ ‡è®°è¯­è¨€ (markup language) # æ ‡è®°è¯­è¨€æ˜¯ä¸€å¥—æ ‡è®°æ ‡ç­¾ (markup tag) # HTML ä½¿ç”¨æ ‡è®°æ ‡ç­¾æ¥æè¿°ç½‘é¡µ # å…¶è¯­æ³•æ ¸å¿ƒå°±æ˜¯åˆ©ç”¨ä¸åŒçš„æ ‡ç­¾å¯¹ç½‘ç»œä¸Šçš„å†…å®¹è¿›è¡Œæ ‡è®°ï¼Œä»è€Œä½¿ç½‘é¡µæ˜¾ç¤ºå‡ºä¸åŒçš„å±•ç¤ºæ•ˆæœ # HTML æ ‡ç­¾æ˜¯ç”±å°–æ‹¬å·åŒ…å›´çš„å…³é”®è¯ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ <html> # HTML æ ‡ç­¾é€šå¸¸æ˜¯æˆå¯¹å‡ºç°çš„ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ <b> å’Œ </b> # æ ‡ç­¾å¯¹ä¸­çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ ‡ç­¾æ˜¯å¼€å§‹æ ‡ç­¾ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒä¸ªæ ‡ç­¾æ˜¯ç»“æŸæ ‡ç­¾ # HTML æ ‡ç­¾ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½å•ç‹¬å‡ºç°ï¼Œå«åšå•æ ‡ç­¾ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚<br /> # å¼€å§‹å’Œç»“æŸæ ‡ç­¾ä¹Ÿè¢«ç§°ä¸ºå¼€æ”¾æ ‡ç­¾å’Œé—­åˆæ ‡ç­¾ # å¦‚ # <h1> # I love U # </h1> # <h2 align="center">I hate U</h2> # h1:æ ‡ç­¾ align:å±æ€§ center:å±æ€§å€¼ # ç”±æ­¤å¯ä»¥çŸ¥é“æ ¼å¼ï¼š # <æ ‡ç­¾ å±æ€§="å±æ€§å€¼">è¢«æ ‡è®°çš„å†…å®¹</æ ‡ç­¾> # <æ ‡ç­¾ å±æ€§="å±æ€§å€¼"/> # <æ ‡ç­¾ /> # <a href="http://www.bing.com">å¿…åº”æœç´¢</a> # <img src="xxx.jpg"/> # <br />

entry.title: 05. Data Parsing, Regular Expressions and re Module
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 05. æ•°æ®è§£æã€æ­£åˆ™è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸reæ¨¡å—

Table of Contents

Data Parsing Overview

Regular Expressions

Concept of Regex

Pros and Cons of Regular Expressions

Regex Syntax

Common Metacharacters

Quantifiers

Greedy vs Lazy Matching

Typical Cases

re Module

Common Functions in re Module

Summary

Complete Code Used in This Section

Data Parsing Overview

In previous sections, we basically mastered the basic skills of scraping entire webpages. However, in most cases, we donâ€™t need the entire webpage content, such as page frameworks, advertisements, notifications, etc. How do we extract only the target data we need? This involves data parsing!

We will learn three parsing methods:

1. re parsing

2. bs4 parsing

3. xpath parsing

These three methods are not limited to standalone use - they can be mixed according to needs. When writing crawlers, weâ€™re completely results-oriented. As the saying goes, it doesnâ€™t matter if itâ€™s a black cat or white cat - a cat that catches mice is a good cat! As long as we can get the data we want, the method doesnâ€™t matter. After mastering these methods, we can then consider performance issues.

Regular Expressions

When it comes to data parsing, regular expressions are indispensable.

Concept of Regex:

Regular Expression is a syntax rule that uses expressions to match strings.

In plain terms, itâ€™s extracting the parts we want from a piece of text/code through a series of expressions. The webpage source code we scrape is essentially a super long string, so using regular expressions to extract content from it is perfect!

Pros and Cons of Regular Expressions:

Pros: Fast speed, high efficiency, high accuracy

Cons: Somewhat difficult for beginners to get started

As long as we can master the logical relationships of regex writing, creating a regular expression to extract page content isnâ€™t actually complex.

Regex Syntax:

Use metacharacters in combinations to match strings. Hereâ€™s a website for testing regular expressions online:

Online Regex Testing Websitehttps://tool.oschina.net/regex/

Metacharacters: Special symbols with fixed meanings

Common Metacharacters:

Quantifiers:

Control how many times the preceding metacharacter appears

Greedy vs Lazy Matching

Pay special attention to these two - lazy matching is what we use most when writing crawlers.

Typical Cases

So we can discover this pattern:

.*? means match as few as possible

.* means match as many as possible

Remember this pattern for now - it will be used when writing crawlers later.

re Module

Now the question is: I know how to write regular expressions, but how do I use them in Python programs?

Observant readers may have noticed that the initials of Regular Expression are â€œreâ€ - thatâ€™s our re module. So we just need to import re in Python programs to use regex.

Common Functions in re Module

1. findall finds all matches, returns a list

2. search will match, but if it finds the first result, it returns that result. If no match, search returns None

3. match can only match from the beginning of the string

4. finditer, similar to findall, but returns an iterator (important)

5. compile, can preload a long regex for convenient later use

6. How to extract specific content from regex?

You can name groups to get specific content from regex matches

Here we can see that by using groups, we can further filter the content matched by regex, making results clearer, more readable, and more valuable.

Summary

In this section, we learned a very important method for data parsing: regular expressions. We also learned about the application of regular expressions in Python: the re module. Through various examples, we practiced using regular expressions.

I hope everyone can continue to work hard with me and enhance our personal abilities~

(You can use your spare time to learn more about computer networking and HTML/frontend knowledge to facilitate our future learning)

For HTML learning, you can refer to my other column HTML Introduction, Advanced and Practice

Complete Code Used in This Section (Comment out parts you donâ€™t want to see when testing for easier observation)

entry.title: 06. Practical: Scraping Movie Top250 with Python Regex
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 06. Practical: Scraping Movie Top250 with Python Regex
ğŸ“Š 913 views | ğŸ‘ 6 likes | ğŸ’¬ 1 comment | â­ 16 favorites

Table of Contents

Introduction

Requirements

Approach

Code Implementation

Complete Code

Results

Summary

Introduction

After learning the basics in previous chapters, we now have the ability to work on small projects. Our target is the movie ranking website we mentioned before - weâ€™ll scrape the Top 250 movies for practice.

Requirements

Scrape the â€œMovie Nameâ€, â€œRelease Yearâ€, â€œRatingâ€, and â€œNumber of Ratingsâ€ from a movie websiteâ€™s Top 250 list, and save them to a file.

Approach

Check the page source code to see if the data is included. If not in the source code, consider JavaScript dynamic loading - youâ€™ll need to find the data source. Otherwise, parse the source code directly with regex.

As we can see, all the data we need is in the source code, so we can directly use the regex method we just learned to extract the data we want!

Code Implementation

Step one, our old friend - get the page source code first:

Following our approach, step two is to observe the source code and write the corresponding regex:

From the page source code, we can see that movie information starts from the <li> tag. Then we find <span class="title"> where we can get the movie name. We use the ?P<groupname> method to name it for easier extraction later. The same applies to the rest - we find the release year, rating, and number of ratings and name them accordingly.

Hereâ€™s a portion of the page source code (one movie info section) for comparison with the regex:

Step three, start matching and save the data to your preferred file format. Iâ€™m using a CSV file here, which is similar to a spreadsheet format. Youâ€™ll need to import the csv library - the complete code is provided below.

At this point, we notice we only scraped the top 25. How do we get the rest?

Scrolling to the bottom, we find the ranking is paginated, not all on one page. This makes sense - requesting 250 items at once means large data transfer, which can cause server congestion and transmission errors.

Clicking to page two, we see the URL changed:

It added â€œ?start=25&filter=â€ at the end. You can probably guess what this means - it starts displaying from rank 25!

Letâ€™s modify the URL and change the start parameter to 0. Sure enough, it shows the first page:

Now the approach is clear - we just need to loop through the source code, incrementing the start parameter by 25 each time, looping 10 times to export all the data we want!

A simple for loop will do, but to avoid overwriting previous data, we need to change the CSV write mode to â€œa+â€ to append subsequent data. Otherwise, weâ€™d only get ranks 226-250.

Complete Code

Remember to replace with your own User-Agent! As explained in previous chapters, just press F12 to open developer tools, go to Network tab, find your User-Agent in the response headers, and replace my headers with yours.

Thereâ€™s room for optimization in this code. Think about how to reduce time and space complexity to improve efficiency. Feel free to share your suggestions!

Results

Hereâ€™s a brief look at my results:

Summary

Today we learned how to use our basic knowledge to build a small program that scrapes a movie ranking website. We used the regex method to scrape information, further familiarizing ourselves with this scraping approach. If youâ€™re interested, try finding other websites to scrape information from.

Remember to be moderate - donâ€™t access too frequently or your IP might get banned!

Also remember to use resp.close() to close the request port to avoid occupying too many ports and being unable to access web pages.

# findall: åŒ¹é…å­—ç¬¦ä¸²ä¸­æ‰€æœ‰çš„ç¬¦åˆæ­£åˆ™çš„å†…å®¹ # lst=re.findall("\d+","æˆ‘çš„ç”µè¯å·æ˜¯:10086,æˆ‘å¥³æœ‹å‹çš„ç”µè¯æ˜¯:10010") lst = re.findall(r"\d+", "æˆ‘çš„ç”µè¯å·æ˜¯:10086,æˆ‘å¥³æœ‹å‹çš„ç”µè¯æ˜¯:10010") # å†™ä¸€ä¸ªræ›´å¥½ print(lst) print(' ')

    python # æ‹¿åˆ°é¡µé¢æºä»£ç  =>requests # é€šè¿‡reæ¥æå–æƒ³è¦çš„æœ‰æ•ˆä¿¡æ¯ =>re import requests import re import csv for rank in range(10): url = 'https://movie.douban.com/top250' + '?start=' + str(25 * rank) + '&filter=' headers = { "User-Agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/104.0.5112.81 Safari/537.36 Edg/104.0.1293.54" } resp = requests.get(url, headers=headers) page_content = resp.text # è§£ææ•°æ® obj = re.compile(r'<li>.*?<div class="item">.*?<span class="title">(?P<moviename>.*?)' r'</span>.*?<p class="">.*?<br>(?P<movieyear>.*?)&nbsp.*?<span ' r'class="rating_num" property="v:average">(?P<moviescore>.*?)</span>.*?' r'<span>(?P<ratingnum>.*?)äººè¯„ä»·</span>', re.S) # å¼€å§‹åŒ¹é… result = obj.finditer(page_content) with open("data.csv", mode="a+", encoding='utf-8', newline='') as f: csvwriter = csv.writer(f) for i in result: print(i.group("moviename")) print(i.group("moviescore")) print(i.group("ratingnum")) print(i.group("movieyear").strip()) # strip()å»é™¤å‰é¢çš„ç©ºæ ¼ dic = i.groupdict() dic['movieyear'] = dic['movieyear'].strip() csvwriter.writerow(dic.values()) f.close() print("over!")

entry.title: 03. HTTP Protocol
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 03. HTTPåè®®

Table of Contents

HTTP Protocol

Basic Concepts

Request

Response

Important Content in Request Headers (Needed for Crawling)

Important Content in Response Headers

Request Methods

Summary

HTTP Protocol

Basic Concepts

Protocol: A gentlemanâ€™s agreement set up between two computers to enable smooth communication. Common protocols include TCP/IP, SOAP, HTTP, SMTP, and moreâ€¦

HTTP: Hyper Text Transfer Protocol - the protocol that browsers and servers follow for data exchange. Itâ€™s used to transfer hypertext from World Wide Web (WWW) servers to local browsers.

The HTTP protocol divides a message into three main parts, whether itâ€™s a request or response:

Request:

Response:

When writing crawlers later, pay special attention to request headers and response headers - these two places usually contain important hidden information.

Important Content in Request Headers (Needed for Crawling):

1. User-Agent: Identity of the request carrier (what sent the request)

2. Referer: Anti-hotlinking (which page did this request come from? Used for anti-crawling)

3. Cookie: Local string data information (user login info, anti-crawling tokens)

Important Content in Response Headers:

1. Cookie: Local string data information (user login info, anti-crawling tokens)

2. Various mysterious strings (requires experience, usually token-related, preventing various attacks and anti-crawling)

Request Methods:

GET: Explicit submission (queries)

POST: Implicit submission (modifications)

Summary

entry.title: 02. Web Request Process Analysis
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 02. Webè¯·æ±‚è¿‡ç¨‹åˆ†æ

Table of Contents

Complete Web Request Process Analysis

Introduction

A Simple Example

1. Server-Side Rendering

2. Frontend JS Rendering

Conclusion

Summary

Complete Web Request Process Analysis

Introduction

In the previous section, we implemented a simple webpage source code scraping task. But fundamentally, how are webpages accessed? How is the source code transmitted to us? This section will explain the web request process analysis, which will help us handle various types of websites with ease and provide basic guidelines for getting started.

So what exactly happens between entering a URL in the browser and seeing the complete webpage content?

A Simple Example

Letâ€™s use Baidu search as an example: When accessing Baidu search, the browser sends this request to Baiduâ€™s server. The server receives this request, loads the corresponding data, and returns it to our browser for display. This might sound obvious, but thereâ€™s an extremely important detail: Baiduâ€™s server doesnâ€™t return a directly displayable page, but rather the page source code (composed of HTML, CSS, JS) mentioned in the previous section. The browser then executes this source code and displays the result to the user.

The specific process is shown in the diagram below:

Now letâ€™s introduce another important concept. Does the page source code we request contain all the data? In other words, is all the data displayed on the current page included in the source code? This brings us to the â€œpage renderingâ€ process.

There are two common page rendering methods:

1. Server-Side Rendering

This is the easiest to understand and the most straightforward. It means that when we request the server, the server directly writes all the data into the HTML, and our browser can directly receive HTML content with data (press F12 to open browser developer tools). For example:

Movie Paradise

Since the data is written directly in the HTML, all visible data can be traced in the page source code. These types of webpages are generally easier to scrape.

2. Frontend JS Rendering

This is slightly more complicated. This mechanism typically involves the first request returning an HTML framework structure from the server, then making another request to the server that actually stores the data. This server returns the data, which is finally loaded in the browser, as shown below:

The advantage of this approach is that the website server can reduce pressure, with clear division of labor and easier maintenance. A typical example is JD.com:

JD.com

You can see that this product is not shown in the source code, but it appears on the page. So when was the data loaded? Through searching, we find a JSON file, indicating that the data is stored in other files and doesnâ€™t exist directly in the source code. This file is obtained through other requests. Double-clicking to open it shows:

Actually, when we scroll the page, JD.com is loading data. To see this process, we need to use the browserâ€™s developer tools (F12):

Select the â€œNetworkâ€ tab, click the clear button to clear the current network activity cache, making it easier to observe the websiteâ€™s next activity.

Now when we scroll down, we can see the newly requested files:

So the content seen on the page is loaded later - the source code from the first request is just the websiteâ€™s framework without content. Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ve encountered this situation when network loading is slow: the webpage framework loads first, followed by images and other content. This is the result of multiple requests.

Conclusion

By discussing these two rendering methods, I just want to tell you that our data doesnâ€™t only come from the page source code. More often, itâ€™s stored in another request. When scraping this type of data, we need to put more effort into finding the target request to get the desired data.

Summary

entry.title: 04. Requests Module Introduction with Three Cases (Sogou Search/Baidu Translate/Douban Movies)
entry.content:
This article was migrated from CSDN blog
Original link: 04. requestsæ¨¡å—å…¥é—¨ä¸ä¸‰ä¸ªæ¡ˆä¾‹

Table of Contents

Introduction

Installing Requests

1. Install via CMD

2. Install in PyCharm

3. Install in Anaconda Virtual Environment

4. Verify Installation

Case 1: Scraping Sogou Search Content

Case 2: Building Your Own Translation Program Using Baidu Translate

Case 3: Reading Douban Movie High Score Rankings

Summary

Introduction

In previous sections, we used urllib to scrape page source code - itâ€™s a built-in Python module, but not our commonly used crawling tool.

The commonly used module for scraping pages is the third-party module - requests. This moduleâ€™s advantage is that itâ€™s even simpler than urllib and handles various requests conveniently.

Installing Requests

Since itâ€™s a third-party module, we need to install it. Installation methods:

1. Install via CMD

â‘  Press Win+R, type cmd, press Enter

â‘¡ Type pip install requests

If installation is slow, use a domestic mirror:

2. Install in PyCharm

If installation is slow, use a domestic mirror:

3. Install in Anaconda Virtual Environment

â‘  Open Anaconda 3 Prompt

â‘¡ Create a virtual environment (skip if you already have one)

Type conda create -n environment_name python=X.X, press Enter

After waiting, the following interface appears, type y, press Enter

After waiting, you can see itâ€™s been created successfully

â‘¢ Activate the virtual environment

Type conda activate environment_name, or activate environment_name

Type pip install requests

If installation is slow, use a domestic mirror:

pip install requests -i https://pypi.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn/simple requests

You can also use conda to install, type conda install requests

Type y, press Enter

After waiting, â€œdoneâ€ appears - installation successful.

4. Verify Installation

â‘  You can import requests in a py file to see if thereâ€™s an error

â‘¡ You can type pip list in the methods mentioned above to view the installed library list (using Anaconda as an example)

You can see requests is now in our installed list - installation complete.

Case 1: Scraping Sogou Search Content

The url can be modified as needed - copy the URL from whichever search page you want to scrape;

ua (User-Agent) needs to be copied from your own response headers mentioned in the previous section.

Lines 9/10 handle a small anti-crawling measure, â€œdisguisingâ€ our Python programâ€™s request UA (User Agent) as a normal browser instead of programming software.

Case 2: Building Your Own Translation Program Using Baidu Translate

This code doesnâ€™t need modification and can be used directly.

Note the URL https://fanyi.baidu.com/sug - through F12 we can see itâ€™s submitted via POST, so we also need to simulate a POST request using the requests.post() API. The response is returned to resp, then processed directly as JSON data (equivalent to a Python dictionary). Printing this JSON directly shows too much complex information. We selectively print the content we need to display our desired translation result with better readability~

Running example:

You can see weâ€™ve perfectly â€œborrowedâ€ Baidu Translateâ€™s results! Quite satisfying for beginners~

Case 3: Reading Douban Movie High Score Rankings

Here we used a clever approach - since the original URL was too long and complex, we took a different path by re-encapsulating a set of parameters, putting all parameters after top_list into param for easier modification later.

headers is the UA we mentioned before - you can change the parameter name as you like~

Here we use GET request, different from Case 2. Itâ€™s easy to understand - as mentioned before, POST is for uploading/modifying, GET is for retrieving/downloading. So Baidu Translate needs to POST the word we want to translate, while Douban Movies needs to GET the information we want.

In GET requests, our param content is automatically appended to the URL, automatically concatenating into that long code we saw at the beginning! Actually, startâ€™s function is which rank to start from, and limitâ€™s function is how many to query at once. Knowing these two conditions, you can write a loop to execute n times to get Douban Moviesâ€™ top 20n ranking details.

Summary

In this section, we learned how to install the requests module, successfully wrote three simple crawler cases, learned about requests usage with two different request methods, increased our learning interest, and boosted our programming confidence. I hope everyone can progress together with me and keep working hard~
